INVESTMENT PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Islamic Republic of Afghanistan (Afghanistan) 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Energy 
Subsectors:  Transmission  and  distribution,  renewable  energy, 
generation 
Themes: Sustainable economic growth, capacity development 
Subthemes:  Fostering  physical  infrastructure  development, 
institutional development 
   
Environment  The  Energy  Sector  Development  Investment  Program  (the 
Assessment  Investment Program) to be financed by the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB), through a multitranche financing facility (MFF) and 
the Government has an environmental assessment and review 
framework.  Each  project  will  have  individual  safeguard 
documents. Tranche 1 was subject to standard environmental due 
diligence  and  classified  as  category  B.  Initial  environmental 
examinations  of  tranche  1  projects  are  in  Supplementary 
Appendixes H, I, J, and K. 
   
Sector Program  The Afghanistan National Development Strategy (ANDS), launched 
Description   by the Government in April 2008, is the country’s strategic platform 
  for development during 2008–2020. Its aim is to promote growth, 
generate  wealth,  and  reduce  poverty  and  vulnerability.  ANDS 
covers  all  key  sectors  and  subsectors,  and  embraces  several 
themes.  One  of  the  main  sectors  is  energy.  ANDS  establishes 
quantitative and qualitative (physical and nonphysical) targets, and 
covers generation, transmission, and distribution. Within the sector, 
ANDS covers investments in new and existing assets, including 
their  management,  maintenance,  and  repair.  The  underlying 
objective  is  to  provide  reliable  and  cost-effective  electricity  to 
industry and people. The proposed MFF finances a medium-term 
slice of a broader Investment Program. It is also consistent with 
ADB’s strategy for the country articulated in the Country Strategy 
and  Program  Update  (CSPU)  2006-2008,  and  the  Country 
Partnership Strategy (CPS) 2009-2013 currently under preparation 
which will be considered early in 2009. The CPS calls on ADB to 
provide financing and advice for infrastructure (roads and railways), 
power and energy, and irrigation. The Government also wants ADB 
to set aside money every year for private sector development and 
transactions. The ADB strategy responds to what the Government 
needs, and focuses in areas where ADB has skills, knowledge and 
information, as well as a reasonable record of success. The CPS 
supports  work  on  institutional  effectiveness,  particularly  those  in 
charge of priority sectors. These interventions include (i) training for 
better planning and project management; (ii) gender mainstreaming; 
(iii)  financial  management,  anticorruption  policy  measures,  and 
fiduciary oversight; (iv) private sector development; (v) safeguard 
management; and (vi) regional cooperation. The CPS also calls on

ii   
ADB to approach financing more programmatically, and proposes in 
particular the use of the MFF. 
 
The  development  of  the  Investment  Program  is  based  on 
assessments  of  technical,  operational,  commercial,  legal, 
financial,  and  other  matters.  These  led  to  the  creation  of  a 
problem  tree  analysis  (Appendix  2),  which  in  turn  led  to  the 
projected  outcome  shown  in  the  design  and  monitoring 
frameworks (DMF) for the Investment Program as a whole and 
tranche 1. The DMFs are in Appendix 1. 
 
The proposed MFF has two important features. First, it finances new 
assets.  Second,  the  Government  will  use  the  Afghanistan 
Reconstruction Trust Fund to cofinance community services in areas 
where power and energy facilities are planned and are being built. 
This benefits Government, people, contractors, and consultants. It 
will also enhance awareness of the villagers on the localized benefits 
of the Program, thereby lowering security risks.  
   
MFF Modality  The MFF is proposed as the modality to extend ADB financing to 
the  Investment  Program.  The  following  seven  points  clearly 
demonstrates the justification of using the MFF modality:  
 
(i)  It provides flexibility to the authorities and ADB. Within the 
proposed maximum financing of $570 million, ADB and the 
Government  can  modify  the  amount  and  timing  of 
contributions under each tranche. 
(ii)  Financing is aligned with project-readiness filters. 
(iii)  The  MFF  allows  ADB  to  enter  into  a  medium-term 
partnership,  thereby  creating  a  stable  financing  plan.  It 
also mixes physical investments with advisory services. 
(iv)  Individual contract packages are significant in size (albeit 
smaller  than  with  stand-alone  projects)  and  limited  in 
number. This invalidates the use of a sector loan approach 
or stand-alone project modalities as alternatives.  
(v)  A program loan would help improve policies but not capital 
investments,  which  are  a  binding  constraint.  An  MFF 
allows ADB, the Government, and other parties to shift 
time and resources away from repetitive processing tasks 
into implementation work.  
(vi)  Subsequent tranches are reasonably well defined, including 
the nature, characteristics, location, and investment plan. 
(vii)  All the conditions precedent for the use of an MFF are in 
place: a strategic framework, a policy framework (with the 
operating  principles  and  undertakings),  an  investment 
program, and a tentative financing plan.  
   
Rationale  The energy sector faces tremendous physical and nonphysical 
challenges, including limited supplies (low generation capacity), 
mounting  transmission  and  distribution  system  gaps,  rising 
technical losses, poor rural energy and electrification coverage,

iii
and inadequate gas and hydropower resources units. The sector 
also faces legal and regulatory shortcomings, as well as gaps in 
financial and management operations [especially of the executing 
agency,  Afghanistan  Electricity  Corporation  (DABS)],  poor 
financial  management,  high  commercial  losses,  and  ineffective 
and inefficient planning and project execution. 
 
The Government has requested ADB financial assistance over 5–
6 years. This assistance is to be channeled through the MFF, 
which will be converted into tranches linked to the readiness of 
individual projects. This approach is also followed for the other 
strategic sectors under the CPS: transport and irrigation. 
   
Investment Program  An investment program has been prepared for the sector. The 
physical  and  nonphysical  outputs  will  lead  to  a  more  reliable 
power  system.  Physical  outputs  include  (i)  rehabilitation, 
augmentation, and expansion of the North East Power System 
(NEPS); (ii) development of distribution systems for load centers 
supplied from NEPS; (iii) increased domestic generation capacity 
through new off-grid greenfield small and mini hydropower plants; 
and (iv) rehabilitation of gas fields. Off-grid rural electrification is 
based on renewable hydropower. 
 
Nonphysical outputs include (i) training for better system operation 
and maintenance; (ii) better planning, project management, and 
systems, including the introduction of a management information 
system;  (iii)  metering,  billing,  and  collection  of  tariffs;  and  (iv) 
thematic coverage, including gender mainstreaming and private 
sector  development.  The  Investment  Program  will  set  up 
mechanisms of teams for monitoring and evaluation, reporting, 
and measuring results. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The Investment Program will lead to a more reliable and cost-
effective power supply for industry and people, leading to faster 
and  sustainable  economic  development.  The  outcome  will  be 
more reliable generation, transmission, and distribution networks, 
and financial sustainability of DABS.  
   
Financing Plan   Long-term  investments  are  estimated  at  $4  billion.  In  the 
immediate term (2008–2012), the priority investments are about 
$2.3 billion. Of this, the Government asked ADB to finance up to 
$570 million.

iv   
ADB will provide MFF of up to the equivalent to $570 million from 
the Asian Development Fund (ADF). The Japan Fund for Poverty

to $12 million. The rest of the financing plan will be distributed 
among  other  development  partners,  including  the  World  Bank, 
Islamic  Development  Bank,  Japan  International  Cooperation 
Agency,  European  Union,  and  United  States  Agency  for 
International Development. The details of the financing plan for the 
program are being worked out.

Allocation and Relending  Tranche 1 financing will be in the form of a grant. All proceeds, 
Terms  except those to be used by the Ministry of Mines (MOM), will be 
onlent to DABS with a 32-year tenor including an 8-year grace 
period, at 1% a year interest during the grace period and 1.5% a 
year  thereafter.  This  creates  a  revolving  pool  of  funds  to  help 
finance other activities in the sector.

Executing Agencies  DABS will be the Executing Agency (EA) for all projects except for 
the Sheberghan Gas Fields Rehabilitation Project for which  MOM 
will be the EA. 
   
Implementation  A program management office (PMO) will be established in DABS 
Arrangements  to manage project execution. It will also perform due diligence on 
new  transactions  (to  be  financed  under  subsequent  tranches). 
MOM will second staff to the PMO to help with the implementation

v
of  the  Sheberghan  Gas  Fields  Rehabilitation  Project.  This 
approach will eliminate the duplication of work by the EAs. 
 
The  EAs  have  limited  capacity.  A  team  of  advisors  will  be 
recruited  to  work  in  the  PMO  to  provide  project  management 
expertise and training. To ensure EA ownership, and to realize all 
operations  efficiently,  the  PMO  will  be  structured  into  teams, 
headed by a director with experience in project management. The 
director will report to the chief executive officer in DABS and a 
minister of MOM. ADB will have direct access to the PMO for 
business  matters  and  to  MOM  and  DABS  for  policy  matters. 
Tranche 1 has earmarked $3 million to cover the costs of the 
PMO. 
 
An implementation plan has been prepared together with a facility 
administration manual. These provide a list of key tasks and a 
forecast  for  contract  awards  and  disbursements.  The 
implementation  plan  defines  reporting  requirements  and 
deadlines. 
   
Procurement  Procurement of works and goods to be financed under the MFF 
will  be  implemented  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). International 
competitive bidding will be used for supply contracts estimated to 
cost more than $500,000 and for works of more than $2 million. 
National competitive bidding will be used for goods and works 
valued  at  more  than  $100,000  and  below  the  thresholds  for 
international competitive bidding. Shopping will be used for goods 
and works equal to or below $100,000. 
 
Limited international bidding may be needed for the Sheberghan 
Gas  Fields  Rehabilitation  Project.  While  this  is  not  an  ideal 
procurement approach, attracting competent contractors for this 
type  of  project  has  been  difficult  in  the  past.  Project 
implementation has been delayed for several years.  
 
For  each  ADF-financed  project,  advance  contracting  for  the 
procurement of equipment, civil works, consulting services, and 
other  expenditures  will  be  permitted,  subject  to  these  being 
eligible  according  to  agreed  upon  procedures,  and  ADB’s 
Procurement  Guidelines  and  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
Retroactive  financing  is  proposed  under  individual  tranches  for 
expenditures  incurred  12  months  before  the  signing  of  the 
corresponding financing agreement, with a ceiling of up to 20% of 
the tranche amount. The Government, MOM, and DABS have been 
informed  that  approval  of  advance  contracting  and  retroactive 
financing does not commit ADB to financing any of the proposed 
projects.

vi   
Consulting Services  The PMO will require consulting services. Firms and individuals 
(national and international) will be engaged to provide advisory 
services in the following areas: (i) project management; (ii) due 
diligence work (technical, commercial, financial, legal, safeguards, 
gender, governance, etc.) for subsequent tranches; (iii) detailed 
design engineering, procurement, and supervision; (iv) safeguard 
management  and  gender  mainstreaming;  (v)  evaluation, 
monitoring, auditing, reporting, and measuring results; and (vi) 
training  and  policy  advice.  Consultants  will  be  selected  and 
engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants using the quality-based selection method.  
 
Single-source selection may be used to recruit a consultant to 
help with the Sheberghan Gas Fields Rehabilitation Project. The 
least-cost  selection  method  will  be  used  to  recruit  external 
auditors and external agencies to monitor the implementation of 
safeguards.  Individual  consultants  may  be  recruited  for  other 
assignments, in accordance with ADB procedures for recruitment 
of individual consultants.  
   
Investment Program  The  Investment  Program  will  benefit  people  and  businesses. 
Benefits and  Benefits  are  derived  from  the  provision  of  less-expensive  and 
Beneficiaries  more reliable electricity to a greater number of people for most of 
the year. Energy will improve welfare and accelerate economic 
growth. The Investment Program will also have gender-related 
benefits,  particularly  as  household  tasks  become  less  labor 
intensive and job opportunities grow. Household will benefit by 
reducing the use of expensive diesel-generated electricity. The 
Investment Program will have minimal impact on the environment. 
In addition to initiating environmental due diligence the Investment 
Program will take a broader view on climate change, particularly in 
the  context  of  energy  conservation,  clean  energy,  renewable 
energy, and system efficiency. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The  key  assumptions  for  success  of  the  Investment  Program 
include (i) timely implementation of projects, (ii) more effective 
institutions,  (iii)  a  commitment  to  reforms  and  the  policy 
framework, (iv) stable regulation arrangements and tariff regime, 
and (v) improvement in security. 
 
One  of  the  main  risks  to  the  Investment  Program  is  that  the 
restructuring  of  DABS  could  be  delayed  or  not  be  completed. 
Other risks include insufficient power imports from neighboring 
countries and inadequate project management.  
 
The modernization of DABS is on course, although the process 
will  require  a  major  political  commitment  and  working  capital 
financing in the short term. Considerable technical assistance is 
being assigned to this task from ADB and other agencies such as 
the  World  Bank.  Electricity  supplies  from  Uzbekistan  are  not 
formally  confirmed,  although  both  parties  have  been  talking

vii
recently.  Supplies  from  Tajikistan  are  scheduled  to  come  on 
stream in 2010, but will only be available between May to August. 
Electricity supplies from Turkmenistan have not been formalized, 
and the gas project to supply Pakistan and India is only on the 
drawing board. The Central Asia-South Asia Regional Electricity 
Market  Project  is  in  the  planning  stage.  This  suggests  that  a 
domestic  supply  is  needed  to  achieve  energy  security.  Kabul 
receives only 2–3 hours of electricity a day.  
 
Project management has been a problem in the past. Capacity is 
lacking, and the systems and procedures are inefficient and slow. 
The establishment of the PMO breaks with past practice, taking a 
holistic view of the management of project tasks and themes.  
 
Security is likely to remain the most difficult problem in the short to 
medium term. This will make it difficult to attract investors and 
contractors,  and  to  implement  projects.  The  MFF  establishes 
community-based,  small-scale  investments  and  contingency 
finance to pay for security. This will not address the core cause of 
the problem, but it might reduce the risk to contractors.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  proposed  (i) 
multitranche financing facility (MFF), and (ii) administration of a grant from the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction (JFPR), both to the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan for the Energy Sector 
Development  Investment  Program  (the  Investment  Program).  The  design  and  monitoring 
frameworks (DMFs) are in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  Devastated by decades of conflict, Afghanistan has one of the lowest electrification 
ratios and energy consumption rates in the world. An estimated 9% of the population has 
access to intermittent public power, and per capita electricity consumption is as low as 21 
kilowatt-hours (kWh) per year. Cities such as Kabul, the capital, get electricity only 2–3 hours a 
day. The shortage of electricity affects people in urban and rural areas alike. It is a binding 
constraint on development.  
 
3.  The Government wants to reverse the situation and has given top priority to the energy 
sector  in  its  midterm  development  program.  This  is  reflected  in  the  Afghanistan  National 
Development  Strategy  (ANDS),1 which  was  approved  in  April  2008  and  submitted  to  the 
international community in Paris in mid-2008. The ANDS calls for investments in infrastructure 
in general, but particularly for energy security. Achieving energy security will require expanding 
and  improving  transmission  and  distribution  networks,  and  increasing  domestic  generation 
capacity by using a mix of hydro and thermal power resources. This will not be straightforward, 
because (i) the power system is underdeveloped and the existing facilities are in a state of 
disrepair (some facilities are well beyond their economic life), (ii) the private sector is too small 
and uninterested in backing such large investments, and (iii) foreign investors are deterred by 
the deteriorating security situation. This places the responsibility mainly on a weak public sector. 
Generating more power domestically will take time. An interim measure is to import electricity 
from neighboring countries. Both the importation of electricity and the development of domestic 
capacity  will  require  the  expansion  and  improvement  of  the  transmission  and  distribution 
systems.  
 
4.  A flagship investment is already in place: the new 220-kilovolt (kV) North East Power 
System (NEPS) that connects Kabul, Pul-e-Khumri, Mazar-e-Sharif, Kunduz, and other load 
centers of northern and eastern Afghanistan. This investment is vital for power imports from 
Tajikistan and Uzbekistan (and later from Turkmenistan). The most important parts of the NEPS 
are being completed. A transmission line in Uzbekistan to connect to NEPS, scheduled to come 
on stream in May 2009, will initially enable 150 MW of power to be supplied to Kabul and other 
centers around NEPS.  
 
5.  Afghanistan Electricity Corporation (DABS), established in March 2008, will be the major 
player in the industry. The former Afghanistan Electricity Organization (DABM), a department of 
the Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW), is being transformed into a new company, DABS, with 
its own statutes, a business strategy and mandate, and an independent management team. 
DABS is a vertically integrated national power utility that will own and operate generation, 
                                                 
1 Islamic Republic of Afghanistan. 2008. Afghanistan National Development Strategy. Kabul.

2     
transmission,  distribution  facilities,  and  the  load  dispatch.2 Given  the  market  conditions  in 
Afghanistan, the probability of the company remaining vertically integrated is high. Since nearly 
80% of energy consumption in Afghanistan is in the form of electricity, this transformation—and 
later the introduction of better operating practices at DABS—represents an essential first step 
toward improving the organization of the sector. The outcome must reduce, and eventually 
eliminate, a binding constraint to economic growth in Afghanistan by producing, transmitting, 
and distributing more electricity for more hours each day to more people and businesses in a 
cost-effective and efficient manner. However, even after the transformation of DABS into a 
company, the tasks ahead are difficult due to the complex issues that need to be resolved. 
 
6.  The main challenges are to put in place a professional and experienced management 
team, enough working capital and development financing, tighter governance systems, and a 
sound tariff regime to support operations. DABS will need to spin off some of its activities inherited 
from DABM, refocus its strategy and business plan on priority areas, and develop partnerships with 
local and international entities. Energy security will be a function of how well DABS addresses 
those issues. DABS will need enormous support over the short to medium term.  
 
7.  The country has natural gas, coal, and hydropower potential. Gas and coal resources 
have been identified mostly in central and northern Afghanistan. However, the lack of long-term 
funding to rehabilitate dilapidated infrastructure, or to investigate and develop reserves, limits 
their viability. Exploration of indigenous resources and development of hydropower potential will 
strengthen domestic generation and improve energy security. In the meantime, the country will 
have to rely on imported power and fuels. The recent international price increases for both were 
huge shocks for an already shaky economy and emphasized the importance of energy security.  
 
8.  The Investment Program is driven by the country’s strategic directions for the sector and 
by a policy framework calling for greater operational and institutional efficiency, cost recovery, 
competition, transparency, and good governance. The strategy is clear. The policy framework 
needs some refinements, especially regarding the tariff regime, aspects of the legal framework, 
divestment, and the energy mix. This work will require major assistance. These shortcomings 
must not stop the development of strategic investments. The investment plan includes short-, 
medium-, and long-term investments, and blends physical with nonphysical interventions. As 
such, the timing of the ADB assistance makes sense.  
 
B.   Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
1.  Challenges 
9.  The energy sector faces tremendous challenges which can be found in the detailed 
problem tree analysis, which is in Appendix 2.  
 
a.  Physical Challenges 
10.  Low Generation Capacity. The total generation capacity in Afghanistan is only 625 
megawatts (MW). Actual load is assessed to be much less (about 400 MW), including 167 MW 
of imported power. Hydropower accounts for 40% of the total capacity. However, because of 
droughts  and  reduced  river  flows,  the  country  has  resorted  to  more  expensive  and 
                                                 
2 The Afghanistan Electricity Organization (DABM), a department of the Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW), 
currently owns and operates the electricity assets of the country. Transfer of assets from DABM to Afghanistan 
Electricity Corporation (DABS) is expected to be completed by March 2009.

3
environmentally-less-friendly  options,  including  diesel  and  oil-fired  generation.  To  replace 
expensive  diesel  and  oil  power,  the  two-pronged  strategic  plan  was  adopted:  importing 
electricity from neighboring countries and developing domestic generation capacity. Afghanistan 
has an estimated 23,000 MW of potential hydropower resources, as well as gas and coal 
reserves.  Major  impediments  to  tapping  such  resources  include  the  limited  financial  and 
business capacity of the private sector, and the limited interest of the international investors. 
Therefore, the public sector will need to take initiative to implement such investments. The role 
of international financing is crucial in this regard.  
 
11.  Underdeveloped and Inefficient Transmission System. The transmission system is 
underdeveloped; only major load centers are serviced. NEPS was intended to fix this problem. 
Since 2003, the aid community has committed $1 billion for such investments. While significant 
progress was made, DABS is short on capacity and cash to maintain NEPS. An outside service 
provider will be needed to handle project management and maintenance, as well as training of 
DABS staff to do the job. The system also needs to be expanded in the southern and western 
parts of the country where coverage is limited.  
 
12.  Underdeveloped and Poorly Managed Distribution System. The Government and 
the development community has funded major rehabilitation and expansion works directed at 
the distribution networks linked to NEPS, but much of the work remains to be done. The 
distribution networks in areas outside NEPS need to be expanded and rehabilitated. Many 
facilities were destroyed during the conflict; others have exhausted their economic life. This 
leads to system inefficiencies, including high technical losses and poor customer service in 
terms of coverage, quality, and consistency.  
 
13.  High Losses. Total losses including technical losses are estimated at 30% of generated 
electricity. A 10% loss is probably acceptable under the conditions in Afghanistan, but the 
balance translates into $30 million a year in financial losses.3 This is too high for a country with 
financial problems and limited electricity coverage. Unless the situation is addressed, it will put 
DABS’s financial sustainability at risk. It will undermine its ability to service consumers and 
make future investments. The alternative is rising subsidies and a deteriorating fiscal situation. 
The budget is already stressed because of declining tax revenues.  
 
14.  Limited Rural Energy and Geographical Electrification Coverage. Many parts of the 
country do not have any electricity service coverage. Where there is coverage, the systems are 
poorly maintained. The multi aid agency-funded National Solidarity Program (NSP), managed 
by  the  Ministry  of  Rural  Rehabilitation  and  Development,  is  a  flagship  initiative  on  rural 
electrification. The NSP supports electrification schemes with installed capacity typically below 
25 kilowatts (kW). Although this fills only a small part of the energy gap in these areas, it is a 
good  initiative.  Larger  schemes  are  planned,  but  most  have  not  come  on  stream.  The 
Renewable Energy and Rural Electrification Subcommittee was established under the Inter-
Ministerial Commission for Energy (ICE) in September 2008 to address this issue. ADB is 
providing technical assistance. Service coverage in rural areas is important because that is 
where the bulk of the population lives.  
 
15.  Untapped Natural Gas Reserves. Afghanistan has natural gas resources, but the physical 
infrastructure supporting their development has been destroyed or is dilapidated. The Government 
is considering rehabilitating domestic gas wells, which would improve the gas supply to consumers, 
                                                 
3  Based on 20% of a total of 1,162.3 gigawatt-hours of power in 2005, or 232.5 megawatt-hours at $0.12 per kWh. 
Source: Ministry of Energy and Water. Forthcoming. MEW Power Sector Strategy. Kabul.

4     
and provide potential fuel for development of new generation capacity to supply NEPS. The 
Ministry  of  Mines  (MOM)  has  sought  external  assistance  to  rehabilitate  gas  fields  for  the 
development of gas-fired power plants. However, MOM has had limited success, largely because it 
has been difficult to find interested investors and contractors. Plans are under way to develop a 
number of fields. In the longer run, gas is an interesting alternative in the energy mix.  
 
16.  Untapped Coal Reserves. The production rates for the coal industry are very low owing to 
years of neglect. Until the end of 2006, the development of coal resources was restricted primarily 
to two state-owned enterprises, with oversight by MOM. Some lease arrangements with private 
operators have been put in place since then. In May 2007, the Government also established the 
Coal Commission, which is responsible primarily for looking into industrial demand and instruments 
with coal as a fuel source. However, no programmatic assistance has been provided to the coal 
sector. This area needs attention, albeit through investments using clean coal technology.  
 
b.   Nonphysical Challenges  
17.  Weak Legal and Regulatory Framework. Many institutions are engaged in different 
parts  of  the  energy  sector,  which  has  made  coordination  difficult.  Legal  and  regulatory 
frameworks  are  in  place.  However,  the  institutions  behind  them  are  weak  and  at  times 
disconnected from DABS, the company producing, transporting, and distributing electricity. This 
has resulted in a weak energy industry that is technically deficient in planning and design. The 
business environment is also unsound. The tariff regime is unpredictable, making cost recovery 
problematic. To resolve these issues, a multisector regulatory body was established early in 
2008, with a mandate to improve policy coordination and information. DABS needs assistance 
on systems and procedures operations, as well as project management.  
 
18.  Corporatization of DABS and Commercialization of the Energy Sector.  In 2008, the 
Cabinet  approved  the  reorganization  of  DABM  into  a  Government-owned  company  (DABS) 
mandated to operate under the Commercial Code and other laws applicable to private entities. The 
Government backed this with a divestment strategy, due to begin in 2009, for the liquidation, 
restructuring, commercialization, and sale of energy assets under state control. The corporatization 
of DABM into DABS is a positive step, but more work is needed to see that it succeeds. High levels 
of assistance are necessary.  
 
19.  Bad Financial Performance of DABS. The Government doubled electricity tariffs in 
2006.4 This  has  to  a  certain  extent  defrayed  diesel  costs  and  will  help  DABS  financially. 
However, the tariff regime was inadequate to start with, and DABS is expected to carry a heavy 
financial burden in the short to medium term. Capital injections and further increases in real 
tariffs will be required to ensure cost recovery.5 DABS also needs to become more effective, cut 
costs, improve billing and tariff collection, and urgently reduce huge technical and commercial 
losses compared to DABM’s past performance. 
  
20.  Commercial Losses and Low Collection Rate. Commercial losses in the system are 
caused mainly by theft, and unbilled energy while collection rates are low. It is estimated that 
only 60% of billings are collected. These problems translate to a financial loss of approximately 
$45 million a year. If this is combined with total losses of $30 million per year (para. 13), the 
financial sustainability of DABS is in doubt. In addition to investments in the system, better 
business and management practices are needed.  
                                                 
4 From an average of $0.0416/kWh to $0.0830/kWh 
5 ADB estimates that the final average tariff to consumers after 2009 will be $0.12–$0.14 per kWh.

5
 
21.  Lack of Qualified Staff. Low salaries and the loss of experts during the conflict have left 
the  industry  without  enough  experienced  professionals  with  the  right  operational,  financial 
management, and technical skills. Current salaries of engineers at DABM are less than 10% of 
market rates in the country, which inhibits DABS in hiring and retaining staff. High staff turnover 
makes capacity development a challenge. The situation is unlikely to change in the short to 
medium term, which implies a higher-than-average level of support during the implementation of 
projects and for longer periods than would otherwise be the case.  
 
22.  Tighter Aid Agency Coordination. The energy sector is currently overseen by an array 
of ministries, agencies and government organizations. This resulted in inefficient allocation of 
foreign assistance leading to gaps and overlaps in the development of the sector. ICE was, 
therefore, established to function as a centralized coordination body.6 Chaired by the Minister of 
Economy, the ICE includes MEW, MOM, and the Ministry of Finance as core members. The ICE 
aims to help the Government design and monitor energy development strategies based on 
commercial  principles.  It  oversees  energy  sector  policy  and  infrastructure  investment 
programming, and coordinates the work of development partners. 
 
2.  Energy Sector Strategy 
23.  The Afghanistan energy sector strategy is a by-product of ANDS and was formulated 
based  on  assessments  done  in  recent  years.  The  strategy  highlights  key  problems  and 
opportunities, and recognizes the challenges ahead. It proposes a vision for the future and actions 
to  deliver  larger  and  more  reliable  supplies,  better  and  larger  transmission  and  distribution 
networks, and more efficient institutions, by developing new legal and regulatory frameworks, and 
additional finance. The strategy outlines quantitative and qualitative targets and focuses on four 
areas: (i) development of new operations and running of existing ones efficiently, (ii) improvements 
in governance, (iii) expansion of rural electrification and development of renewable energy, and (iv) 
development of effective institutions. The energy sector strategy is summarized in Appendix 3. 
 
3.  Targets 
24.  The objective of the strategy is to get close to, or surpass, the following benchmarks 
projected under the Afghanistan Compact7 by 2010: (i) electricity to reach at least 65% of 
households  in  major  urban  areas,  (ii)  electricity  to  reach  at  least  90%  of  non-residential 
establishments in major urban areas, (iii) at least 25% of rural households to have access to 
electricity, and (iv) at least 75% cost recovery from national power grid.  
 
4.  Energy Sector Investment Program 
25.  The Government produced a development master plan in 2004, which is outdated and 
has been revised. A new energy sector investment program has been developed, which has 
identified projects; several projects have been assigned to different development partners. This 
work has been managed through the ICE. The current Investment Program will cost more than 
$4 billion up to 2015 while the shorter-term Investment Program will cost approximately $2.3 
billion. ADB has been asked to finance a slice of the Investment Program. The financing plan 
remains tentative, although aid agencies such as the World Bank are committed to specific 
transactions. ADB will take a programmatic approach to financing by using an MFF.   
                                                 
6 ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance to Afghanistan for Support to the Inter-Ministerial Commission for Energy. Manila. 
7 The London Conference on Afghanistan. 2006. The Afghanistan Compact. London.

6     
5.  External Assistance  
26.  The  NEPS  has  been  the  focus  of  external  assistance  in  the  energy  sector.  Major 
development partners include ADB, India, German development cooperation through KfW, United 
States Agency for International Development (USAID), and World Bank (Appendix 4). An account 
of past performance is not possible as few projects have been evaluated. This also applies to ADB. 
Through development agencies’ discussions prevalent in the ICE meetings and joint portfolio 
reviews by different aid agencies which have commenced in the past, it has been clarified that the 
portfolios have several common characteristics in strategy and lessons learned (paras. 27–31).  
 
6.  ADB Operations and Sector Strategy  
27.  The Country Strategy and Program Update (CSPU) 2006-2008 for Afghanistan places 
energy sector development as one of its top priorities. Transport, which accounts for the bulk of 
the current portfolio, will remain a priority ADB operations governed by the CSPU under which 
ADB provided financial and advisory assistance to transport, energy, and agriculture.8 The 
rehabilitation of power infrastructure, particularly transmission and distribution lines, and the 
establishment of a national power transmission grid were priorities in the energy sector. The 
ADB program also focused on facilitation of power trading and interconnection with neighboring 
countries.  Similarly,  ADB  has  supported  the  development  of  hydropower  and  natural  gas 
through technical assistance. 
 
28.  The Country Partnership Strategy (CPS) for Afghanistan (2009-2013), which will be 
considered  early  in  2009,  makes  energy  the  top  priority.  The  new  strategy  for  the  sector 
represents a  continuation  of  the format.  The  objective  remains  broadly  the  same,  but  the 
business model is different. Investments and institutions are supported in a more programmatic 
fashion through the combination of physical and nonphysical investments. The new strategy 
attaches  special  importance  to  themes,  particularly  gender  and  development  for  gender 
mainstreaming, capacity, governance, and private sector development. The strategy is also 
aligned with a regional cooperation and integration plan. ADB has three flagship projects in this 
area, one approved and two in development. The ADB strategy is in line with the ANDS and is 
supported by the Government.  
 
7.  Lessons  
29.  ADB has several ongoing projects. None has yet been evaluated independently by the 
Operations Evaluation Department. Nevertheless, based on internal portfolio reviews and project 
performance reports prepared by country and sector teams, several lessons can be highlighted: 
 
(i)  Most projects have been prone to cost overruns and are far behind schedule. This 
is  a  function  of  bad  security  and  rising  investment  costs  (because  of  higher 
international materials and equipment prices, and a rising security cost premium). 
However, some projects would have benefited from better planning and design, as 
well as more realistic cost estimates.  
 
(ii)  Most transactions failed to attract the interest of top contractors, largely because of 
the security situation. This has led to higher-than-expected bid prices, resulting in 
financing gaps. However, more and better marketing of the business opportunities 
might have helped. 
                                                 
8 ADB. 2005. Country Strategy and Program Update (2006–2008): Islamic Republic of Afghanistan. Manila.

7
 
(iii)  The use of design-build approaches has merits, but when only one contractor is 
bidding it also has risks. This has led to changes in project scope, sometimes with 
dubious  justification.  The  Government  often  responded  positively  to  change 
requests, leading to financial commitments that it was not able to always meet. This 
was also prevalent in transport projects. The inability to make good on commitments 
has put contracts at risk, and ADB has often been asked to come to the rescue.  
 
(iv)  ADF  is  the  only  means  ADB  has  to  do  business  in  Afghanistan.  The  current 
allocation arrangements, which require funds to be pledged to projects within a given 
fiscal  year,  may  have  contributed  to  two  problems:  (a)  larger-than-needed 
transactions, and (b) the delinking of financing plans from project readiness. This has 
resulted in cost overruns and ultimately the restructuring of projects and financings. 
The ADF allocation system does not need to be changed because of this; the 
reliance on stand-alone projects does. Specifically, a programmatic approach for all 
priority activities under the CPS might be a better way to deal with this problem.  
 
(v)  The approval of investment projects without proper power purchase agreements 
(PPAs)  up  front  is  a  bad  practice.  This  is  the  situation  with  the  power 
interconnection with Uzbekistan. Although the situation is being managed, the 
main  lesson  is  not  to  start  regional  projects  without  formal  commercial 
agreements in place.  
 
30.  Another lesson is that projects must have better and more detailed implementation 
plans, as well as project implementation manuals up front. As the institutional capacity in the 
country is weak, local teams cannot be expected to start things from scratch. This leads to 
startup delays. In addition, sound organizational arrangements are lacking at the level of the 
executing agencies (EAs). A more holistic project management approach ought to replace the 
standard project management unit concept. The standard approach works for some projects, 
but the institutional memory disappears once these are completed. The combination of project 
management with the execution of institutional reforms linked to the sector and the projects 
makes more sense. This is especially important in financing channeled through MFFs. With 
regard to ADB oversight, recent experience has shown that the resident mission in Kabul and 
the teams at headquarters need to work more closely together from the outset. The concept of 
“delegated” and “non-delegated” projects does not work well if this disconnects technical and 
administrative  tasks,  responsibilities,  and  accountabilities.  A  joint  venture  approach  might 
overcome this problem.  
 
31.  The capacity of the resident mission has also been a problem. The office has dedicated 
professionals, but it needs more experienced project management expertise, and more efficient 
systems and procedures, including project administration oversight and reporting. The skills mix 
deficiency is being corrected through the redeployment of new experts to the field, and through 
new leadership. A detailed action plan to correct other weaknesses has been defined and will 
be implemented in full shortly.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
32.  The expected impact of the Investment Program will be a larger and more cost-effective 
power supply to all customers, resulting in sustainable economic development. The outcome of

8     
the Investment Program will be (i) reliable generation, transmission, and distribution networks; 
(ii)  financial  sustainability  of  DABS;  and  (iii)  better  power  sector  regulation  and  overall 
institutional effectiveness.  
 
B.  Outputs 
 
1.  General 
33.  The Investment Program will create a more reliable power system. This will be a function 
of  (i)  the  rehabilitation,  augmentation,  and  expansion  of  the  NEPS;  (ii)  development  of 
distribution systems at load centers supplied from the NEPS; and (iii) more domestic generation 
capacity through on- and off-grid small and mini greenfield hydropower plants, and rehabilitation 
of gas fields. Off-grid rural electrification programs will rely on the development of renewable 
hydropower, providing rural population access to electricity. 
 
34.  Other outputs of the Investment Program will include (i) better system operation and 
maintenance; and (ii) enhanced planning and project management, including the introduction of 
management information system (MIS) and better metering, billing, and collection of tariffs. 
DABS will be a target for assistance. A PMO will be established to undertake (i) technical work 
(design and supervision); (ii) provide legal services (contracts and bidding processes); (iii) 
safeguard management and gender mainstreaming; (iv) finance and administration (to tighten 
up on systems, procedures, funding, audits, controls, records, and cash management); (v) 
reporting, evaluations, and results measurement; and (vi) technical assistance to train staff on 
project management, planning, policy refinements, and investment program development. The 
PMO will also have due diligence experts to prepare the next generation of priority investments. 
The  office  will  also  have  a  communications  function.  The  intention  is  to  work  on  broad 
institutional matters, while addressing day-to-day operational and project execution.  
 
2.  Program Outputs 
35.  Tranche 1. Physical outputs will include (i) rehabilitating distribution systems in the northern 
cities of Kunduz and Baghlan, (ii) constructing a new 220 kV transmission line from Kunduz to 
Taloqan, (iii) small and mini hydropower plants in Badakhshan and Bamyan Provinces, and (iv) 
rehabilitating gas fields in Sheberghan. Nonphysical outputs will include (i) the establishment and 
optimal functioning of the PMO, (ii) development of a management information system to efficiently 
manage the Program, and (iii) capacity building and training for effective management, operation 
and  maintenance  of  NEPS,  as  well  as  project  management  (procurement,  contract  awards, 
supervision, and design work), due diligence for new projects, safeguard management, gender 
mainstreaming work for all tranches, finance and administration controls, and basic training. All 
advisory packages will be supported by consulting services mandates. Details of physical and 
nonphysical outputs of the Tranche 1 Project are in Appendix 5. 
 
36.  Subsequent  Tranches.  Subsequent  tranches  will  build  on  the  results  of  tranche  1. 
Indicative  physical  outputs  will  include  rehabilitating  and  constructing  of  transmission  lines, 
distribution systems, and new hydropower generation. The three additional tranches will expand 
NEPS to the south of Kabul where connection to the national grid is badly needed. Nonphysical 
outputs will include (i) development of a metering program in load centers covered by NEPS, (ii) 
introduction and upgrading of DABS’s billing system, (iii) development of an action plan to improve 
tariff collection, and (iv) institutional strengthening and capacity building of DABS with the objective 
of enabling the company to operate on a commercial basis. Descriptions of indicative projects to be 
financed under subsequent tranches are in Appendix 6.

9
 
C.  Multitranche Financing Facility Modality 
 
37.  The  MFF  is  proposed  as  the  modality  to  extend  ADB  financing  to  the  Investment 
Program. The following seven points clearly demonstrates the justification of using the MFF 
modality: 
 
(i)  The  modality  provides  flexibility  to  ADB  and  the  Government.  Within  the 
proposed maximum financing of $570 million, ADB and the Government can 
modify the amount and timing of ADB contributions under each tranche. This is 
important  in  case  the  Government  can  raise  additional  financing  from  other 
sources (such as the private sector or other aid agencies), or if the Government 
needs more time to finalize specific project packages. The other key element is 
that the financing to be provided by ADB can be closely linked to the availability 
of  resources  within  ADB,  and  to  full  compliance  with  warranties  and 
representations made under the framework financing agreement (FFA). 
 
(ii)  Financing under the MFF can be aligned to specific technical, safeguard, legal, 
and other project-readiness filters. The authorities can make loan conversions 
under the MFF as and when projects are ready for execution. This approach 
facilitates  advance  actions,  including  documentation  preparation,  and  the 
establishment  of  relevant  administrative  arrangements.  The  MFF  also  allows 
ADB, the Government, and its partners to link more closely financing to changes 
in the cost of projects bundled under each tranche. This avoids cost overruns. 
 
(iii)  The  MFF  allows  ADB  to  enter  into  a  medium-term  partnership  with  the 
Government and DABS, establishing stability and credibility at the level of the 
financing  plan.  The  MFF  mixes  physical  investments  with  advisory  services. 
Advisory  services  include  financing  to  advance  work  on  capacity  and  policy 
actions, which can be precursors to making physical investments. 
 
(iv)  The  individual  contract  packages  are  smaller  than  stand-alone  operations, 
although they are still substantial, and limited in number. This invalidates a sector 
loan approach and stand-alone project modalities as alternatives. However, the 
state  of  energy  facilities  is  poor,  impairing  energy  security  and  economic 
performance. The efficiency gains would not be the same if any of these other 
modalities were used. The MFF will also lower costs, although this is not the 
main by-product. 
 
(v)  A program loan would help improve policies but not capital investments, which 
are  a  binding  constraint.  By  channeling  funding  through  an  MFF,  ADB,  the 
Government, and other parties can shift time and resources away from repetitive 
processing tasks into implementation work.  
 
(vi)  Subsequent  tranches  are  reasonably  well  defined,  including  the  nature, 
characteristics, location, and investment plan. 
 
(vii)  All the conditions precedent for the use of an MFF are in place: strategy or road 
map, policy framework, investment program, and financing plan. The modality 
also moves the analytical work up front, leaving resources and multiple entry 
points for ADB and its partners to focus on execution, capacity, and reforms.

10    
ADB and its partners have agreed upon decision-making criteria and filters for 
the provision of financing, including specific warranties and representations and 
covenants leading to suspension and cancellation of financing. 
 
38.  The status of MFF preconditions is as follows: 
 
(i)  Strategy. The strategic framework or road map is sound. The main components 
are provided with the expected results. 
 
(ii)  Policy framework. The policy framework is less solid than the strategy and will 
need refinements. However, the main building blocks are in place. DABS and 
MOM need to ensure that the main principles are adhered to: cost recovery; 
recurrent  expenditure  financing;  best  practice  approaches  on  safeguards, 
governance, financial management, procurement, and anticorruption measures; 
further  sector  restructuring;  introduction  of  a  firmer  tariff  regime;  and  better 
project management and agency accountability. 
 
(iii)  Investment  Program.  The  Government  has  prepared  a  medium-  term 
investment  program  calling  for  investments  of  about  $4  billion.  Short-term 
investment priorities will cost about $2.3 billion. Both short and medium-term 
investment program are shown in Table 1. 
 
(iv)  Financing plan. The overall program of investments still lacks a firm financing plan, 
although the short-term package has firmer plans. ADB is one of the financiers, 
together with Japan (through JFPR), USAID, KfW, the European Union, India, Iran, 
Islamic  Development  Bank,  and  World  Bank.  If  financing  is  not  secured,  the 
Investment Program will still continue but at a slower pace. The national budget and 
the private sector are not serious financing options.  
 
D.  Energy Sector Investment Program 
 
39.  Investment requirements in the energy sector for the medium term total about $4 billion. 
Of this, some $2.3 billion are the more pressing investments (Table 1). The Government has 
asked ADB to take a slice of this smaller program and to support it over 4–5 years through an 
MFF. The amount proposed is $570 million (Table 2). A set of investments have been prepared. 
These are to be done in four tranches, with the first totaling $164 million (Table 3). Details of the 
cost estimates of this MFF and tranche 1 components are in Appendix 7.

1.  Financing Plan and Conditions 
40.  The Government has asked ADB to finance up to the equivalent of $570 million to help 
finance the Investment Program. Tranche 1 will involve JFPR cofinancing of $12 million.  
 
41.  ADB financing will be provided from ADB’s Special Funds resources, in accordance with 
relevant ADB policies9 subject to modification that may be included under individual financing 
agreements. The implementation period will be 8 years. The Investment Program will consist of 
individual tranches, which terms may vary. The MFF will finance civil works, equipment and 
goods, consulting services, and recurrent costs. All proceeds, except those to be utilized by 
MOM, will be relent to DABS with a tenor of 32 years, including an 8-year grace period, and 
                                                 
9  ADB. 2005. Pilot Financing Instruments and Modalities. Manila; and ADB. 2008. Mainstreaming the Multitranche 
Financing Facility. Manila.

12    
interest rate of 1% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter. This is 
intended to bring financial discipline to the DABS and create a revolving pool of funds for use in 
the energy sector, such as system expansion, rural electrification, and targeted tariff subsidies 
to the poor and vulnerable. Specific methodology shall be agreed during the implementation of 
the Investment Program within two years after grant effectiveness of tranche 1. 
 
42.  The Government will submit a periodic financing request (PFR) for each tranche, which 
will be reviewed by ADB in accordance with the FFA. If approved, financing will come from the 
MFF. The Government has submitted the first PFR, requesting $164 million to help finance tranche 
1 project. The terms and conditions for subsequent tranches will be subject to (i) the availability of 
ADB Special Funds resources; (ii) Afghanistan’s access to such resources pursuant to ADB’s 
Graduation Policy and the requirement of the ADF donors; and (iii) the availability of ADB Special 
Funds resources to Afghanistan pursuant to then-applicable policies concerning allocation of, and 
eligibility for, such funds. Adherence to undertakings made in the FFA and individual tranche 
financing agreement covenants will be conditions for financing approval.  
 
43.  The  last  date  for  any  disbursements  under  any  tranche  will  be  by  30  June  2017. 
Afghanistan is expected to submit the last PFR no later than 31 December 2012. The period of 
availability of tranches will lapse 12 months from the date of Board approval of the MFF.  
 
44.  In addition, the JFPR will provide $12 million in financing for off-grid, rural electrification 
projects. Basic data of the JFPR is presented in Appendix 8. JFPR report is in Supplementary 
Appendix L. The financing plan for tranche 1 is in Table 4.

2.  Asian Development Fund IX Grant  
45.  The Board approved the policy paper on the revised framework for ADF grants on 26 
September 2007.10 This policy provides that, for countries eligible for grant assistance, the 
percentage of financing on a grant basis in such country will be based on its debt-distress 
classification. As Afghanistan is classified as a country with a high risk of debt distress, it is 
eligible to receive 100% grant financing in tranche 1. 
 
3.  Filters for Financing Tranches 
46.  Financing  may  be  made  available  from  ADB,  provided  the  Investment  Program 
continues to be implemented in accordance with the general understandings and expectations 
on which the MFF is based, as contained in the FFA. Progress towards achieving the expected 
outcome and outputs set out in the DMF for the energy sector and the Investment Program will 
be part of the decision-making criteria (and filters) for continuing ADB support. Furthermore, 
                                                 
10 ADB. 2007. Revising the Framework for Asian Development Funds Grants. Manila.

13
compliance with the policy framework, safeguard requirements, social development policies, 
and all other undertakings contained in the FFA will also determine ADB’s decision to continue 
financing of individual tranches. 
 
47.  If a decision has to be made during the early stages of implementation of tranche 1, 
when results most likely would not been achieved yet, ADB’s decision to process additional 
financing  tranches  would  be  made  based  on  the  level  of  commitment  and  efforts  of  the 
Government and EAs to achieve the outcome set forth in the DMF. Nonphysical tasks agreed 
upon that have a direct effect on the outputs expected from the Investment Program (e.g., 
assumptions and mitigation of risks in the DMF pertaining to the Government and the EAs, such 
as tariff and security issues) will be primary factors in ADB decisions.
