E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
1.  Management of the Investment Program 
48.  DABS will be responsible for the overall implementation of the Investment Program, 
except for the Sheberghan Gas Fields Rehabilitation Project, for which MOM will be the EA. A 
PMO will be established in DABS to manage the implementation of all projects. This will include 
due diligence for new transactions under the Investment Program. Staff will be seconded from 
MOM to the PMO to help implement the Sheberghan Gas Fields Rehabilitation Project. 
 
49.  Given  the  limited  capacity  and  resources  of  the  EAs,  significant  assistance  will  be 
required to implement the Investment Program in a timely manner. The PMO will be supported 
by  a  core  team  of  advisers  recruited  from  the  domestic  and  international  markets.  These 
advisers will help execute projects, handle themes, and provide training. The PMO will be 
managed by a director with experience in project management. The PMO will be divided into 
teams, each with a leader and experts to provide specific support. The PMO will also have a 
budget  line  to  engage  the  services  of  long-  and  short-term  experts.  Details  of  the  PMO 
mandates are in Appendix 9. The teams are as follows: 
 
(i)  Director (front office). The person in charge of the PMO will be engaged for at 
least 5 years and will be given a mandate to run the PMO daily operations 
without Government interference. The director will report to the chief executive of 
DABS. The director will have track record and project management expertise.  
 
  (ii)  Technical. An expert in energy and power engineering will lead this team, which 
will also include experts on transmission and distribution, hydropower, and gas 
sector operations. Its mandate will be to deal with all operational or technical 
matters during implementation, handle design work on subsequent tranches, and 
supervise contracts. The team will provide inputs on the procurement documents 
and help pre-qualify and qualify bidders as well as evaluate bids in conjunction 
with other teams (including the legal team). 
 
  (iii)  Legal. This team will provide legal oversight, including on the preparation of 
procurement documents, bidding management, prequalification and qualification 
of contractors and/or investors, bid awards, preparation of contract documents, 
contract  variations,  and  reporting  to  ADB  on  FFA  undertakings  and  loan 
covenants.  The  legal  team  will  provide  checks  and  balances,  and  introduce 
quality control and fiduciary oversight.

14    
  (iv)  Finance and administration. This will be one of the most important functions 
from the point of view of funds management, fiduciary oversight, record keeping, 
audits, and reporting. The team will be managed by a person with a track record 
in  financial  management.  All  withdrawal  applications,  bank  accounts,  and 
payment  instructions  will  be  channeled  through  this  team.  ADB  will  provide 
training  on  financing  management,  anticorruption  works,  controller  functions, 
record keeping and reporting. 
 
(v)  Safeguard and gender mainstreaming. This team will review all new project 
designs, assist in the processing, check on the implementation work, and report 
on  the  compliance  of  ADB  safeguard  policies  and  procedures.  Given  the 
importance  of  gender  mainstreaming,  the  team  will  engage  the  services  of 
experts on the subject. ADB will have direct access to this team for the purposes 
of monitoring performance on these Tranches. 
 
  (vi)  Due diligence. The PMO will engage experts to help prepare of new projects 
under the Investment Program. This team will be involved with technical, legal, 
financial,  commercial,  economic,  social,  safeguard,  governance,  and  other 
matters. ADB will provide guidance and support regarding criteria, and rules and 
procedures. 
 
  (vii)  Results measurement. The PMO will outsource the measurement of results to a 
local institute. The methodology for this work is being worked out. ADB will work 
directly with the institute to ensure that the approach is consistent with others 
adopted for energy projects. 
 
  (viii)  Communications.  The  PMO  will  engage  the  services  of  a  team  to  provide 
regular communications support. The work will include developing a strategy and 
action plan. ADB will provide guidance and support with respect to outcomes and 
outputs. The idea is to communicate actions being taken, as well as successes. 
 
  (ix)  Capacity building. One of the most important components of the PMO work is 
the establishment of an advisory team to help DABS, MOM, and other institutions 
involved in the sector to do their jobs better. Training will include sector planning 
and  project  management,  financial  management,  policy  works,  and  DABS 
restructuring (including commercial and operational assistance). The team will 
work with a pool of Afghan nationals, at least two in each critical task, who will be 
seconded from both DABS and MOM. The idea is to have enough critical mass 
to handle work on accounts of high staff turnover during the operation of the 
PMO.  
  
2.  Implementation Period 
50.  The Investment Program is scheduled for execution over 8 years, including procurement 
and construction activities. All priority investments and institutional support will be completed by 
31 December 2016 at the latest. The MFF utilization period is until 30 June 2017. The physical 
implementation  of  tranche  1  will  be  completed  by  31  December  2013.  An  implementation 
schedule is in Appendix 10.

15
3.  Implementation Plan and Project Readiness 
51.  Implementation Plan. A detailed implementation plan for tranche 1 (Appendix 11), backed 
by a facility administration manual (Supplementary Appendix M) has been prepared. These plans 
will be given to the PMO as a reference to kick-start implementation. A management information 
system (MIS) will be set up to record and report information for management decisions. ADB 
program supervision teams will use the same MIS. The implementation plan has contract awards 
and disbursement projections. The subsequent tranche projects are also identified, including their 
nature, characteristics, and locations.  
 
52.  Project Readiness. Preliminary designs or feasibility studies have been prepared for all 
tranche 1 projects, except for the JFPR cofinanced mini hydropower plants in Badakhshan and 
Bamyan  provinces.  The  identification,  selection,  planning,  and  design  of  potential  mini 
hydropower sites under JFPR will be carried out in the first half of 2009. This will require 
technical assistance to be financed by JFPR. Subsequent tranche projects have been identified, 
but the final due diligence on them will be conducted under tranche 1. The Investment Program 
is precise in terms of the location and nature of projects. The investment plan has also been 
worked out, but further due diligence is needed. In particular, safeguard compliance requires 
special studies for each of the projects and safeguard plans. These will be done as part of the 
due diligence process.  
 
53.  For all tranche 1 projects, due diligence has been performed to assess their technical, 
economical, and financial viability. The concurrence of the Government and EAs were obtained 
for all tranche 1 projects. The Government also agreed with the tentative list of subsequent 
tranche projects. All tranche 1 projects involving physical investment have been classified as 
category B in terms of environmental impact, and initial environmental examination (IEE) reports 
have been prepared. Land acquisition and resettlement (LAR) plans have been prepared for 
projects that involve such issues. An environmental assessment and review framework (EARF) 
and  a  LAR  framework  have  been  prepared  for  the  JFPR,  because  project  details  will  be 
available only during implementation in 2009.  
 
4.  Procurement 
54.  Procurement of works and goods to be financed under the MFF will be undertaken in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
International competitive bidding will generally be used for supply contracts estimated to cost more 
than $500,000 and for works that cost more than $2 million. National competitive bidding (NCB) 
will be used for goods and works above $100,000 and below their international competitive 
bidding thresholds. Shopping will be used for goods and works equal to or below $100,000. 
 
55.  In tranche 1, limited international bidding (LIB) is envisaged to procure a contractor for 
the Sheberghan Gas Fields Rehabilitation Project. Bidding for this project failed on several 
occasions since 2004 to the present because of no interest expressed by third parties.11 USAID 
has encountered the same problem in seeking bidders for more or less identical works in a field 
adjacent to Sheberghan. After several failed bid attempts, USAID finally issued a contract to a 
firm in August 2008—roughly 2 years after initiating the bid. One scenario for Sheberghan is to 
work with the same USAID-funded contractor, which will require LIB. This approach is not 
                                                 
11 ADB. 2003. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the 
Islamic Republic of Afghanistan for the Emergency Infrastructure Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Project. 
Manila.

16    
envisaged for subsequent tranche projects, although it cannot be ruled out. LIB will only be 
used in exceptional circumstances, always backed by proper due diligence and following due 
process with respect to ADB procurement rules.  
 
56.  While the procurement plan for the Investment Program as a whole is still tentative, the 
plan for tranche 1 is firm (Appendix 12). It will be updated every 6–12 months, covering the next 
18  months  of  procurement  activities.  Section  3  of  the  procurement  plan  summarizes  the 
modifications or clarifications to the Government's procedures that are needed to carry out NCB 
under ADB financing. The PMO will work on this aspect through its technical and legal teams.  
 
5.  Consulting Services 
57.  Consultants will be selected and engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The quality-based selection method 
will  generally  be  used  to  attract  interest  from  qualified  firms,  which  tend  to  avoid  cost 
competition  in  a  volatile  environment.  ADB  has  had  experiences  in  Afghanistan  with 
substandard consultants being recruited through the quality- and cost-based selection method. 
This resulted in poor quality work, delays, and cost overruns. Controlling progress, quality, cost, 
and safety of construction works in Afghanistan is widely recognized as a difficult task. The 
performance of the consultant affected significantly the quality of the output. The quality of 
consulting services is a success factor. 
 
58.  For tranche 1, single-source selection is proposed for the recruitment of implementation 
consultants during the Sheberghan Gas Fields Rehabilitation Project for the reasons as those 
justifying LIB. Individual consultants may also need to be recruited for specific assignments 
under the PMO mandate, in accordance with ADB’s procedures for recruitment of individual 
consultants. The least-cost selection method will be used to recruit external auditors and 
experts to monitor the implementation of safeguard plans. The procurement plan with tentative 
consulting services for the Investment Program and for tranche 1 is in Appendix 12. The terms 
of reference of consultants under tranche 1 are summarized in Appendix 13. 
 
6.  Advance Contracting and Retroactive Financing 
59.  Advance contracting and retroactive financing are proposed for certain activities under 
each tranche. The Government was informed that for expenditures incurred before tranche 
effectiveness  to  be  eligible  for  retroactive  financing,  procurement,  consultant  recruitment 
procedures, and other expenses must fully comply with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines and the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. When the tranche becomes effective, up to maximum of 
20% of proceeds may be used to retroactively finance eligible expenditures incurred during the 
period  not  exceeding  12  months  before  signing  of  the  relevant  financing  agreement.  The 
Government  may opt for advance contracting  without  retroactive financing. In that case,  the 
procurement procedures completed under advance contracting do not conclude with the award of 
contract until after the tranche becomes effective. The Government and the EAs have been 
informed that approval of advance contracting and retroactive financing does not commit ADB to 
finance any of the proposed projects. 
 
7.  Disbursement Arrangements 
60.  Loan disbursements will be in accordance with ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook 
(2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  the  disbursement  guidelines.  Direct  payment 
procedures will generally be used for large civil works and consultancy services contracts, as

17
well as turnkey contracts. Commitment procedures may be used for large turnkey contracts, and 
supply and delivery contracts. 
 
61.  EAs will independently establish their respective imprest accounts at a bank acceptable 
to ADB, with initial advances equivalent to the estimated eligible project expenditures for the 
next  6  months  or  $100,000,  whichever  is  lower.  The  imprest  account  will  be  established, 
managed, and liquidated in accordance with the Loan Disbursement Handbook, and detailed 
arrangements agreed to by the Government and ADB. Statement of expenditure procedures will 
be used to reimburse eligible expenditures, or to liquidate and replenish the imprest account for 
any individual payment less than $50,000. The flow of fund is shown in Appendix 14. 
 
8.  Anticorruption Policy  
62.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  Government  and  the  EAs.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance, 
accountability, and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its 
agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to projects under 
the Investment Program. To support these efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption 
Policy are included in the grant regulations and the bidding documents for the Investment 
Program. In particular, all contracts financed by ADB in connection with the Investment Program 
shall include provisions specifying the right of ADB to audit and examine the records and 
accounts of the EAs, and all contractors, suppliers, consultants, and other service providers as 
they  relate  to  the  Investment  Program.  In  case  corrupt,  fraudulent,  collusive,  or  coercive 
practices are found under any activities within the tranches, ADB will automatically cancel the 
MFF and the concerned tranches. This position has been made clear to the Government.  
 
9.  Financial Accounting and Auditing 
63.  The EAs will independently (i) maintain separate accounts for each of their projects 
under the Investment Program; (ii) have such accounts audited annually, in accordance with 
appropriate  auditing  standards  applied  by  independent  auditors  whose  qualifications  and 
experience are acceptable to ADB; (iii) furnish certified copies of such audited project accounts, 
audited financial statements, and the auditors’ opinion (including the opinions on the use of the 
tranche proceeds) and compliance with the financial covenants of the tranche agreement; and 
(iv) provide such other information concerning the audit requested. The independent auditors 
will be engaged and financed by the Government or the EAs. 
 
10.  Project Performance and Monitoring 
64.  The PMO will establish a project performance monitoring team. This will set up base case 
variables for the Investment Program (in line with the DMF and problem tree analysis), collect data 
for performance monitoring, process it and submit it to the PMO director and ADB. The key 
indicators and assumptions are in the DMF. Some of these may need to be changed or modified 
over time, and new ones added. The variables deal with impact, outcomes, and outputs. The ADB 
transaction  and implementation teams  will prepare  periodic reports on overall progress. This 
information will be shared with the Board. A Board information paper will also be submitted 
annually as part of the MFF operations. Further, the Board will be informed on all PFRs, including 
information on safeguard assessments and plans. Any major mishap at the level of the Investment 
Program or individual tranches (with respect to ADB policies and procedures, or with undertakings 
and covenants under the FFA and the tranche agreements) will be reported to the Board. These 
will also trigger the suspension or cancellation of the MFF and its tranches.

18    
11.  Project Review 
65.  ADB  will  field  an  inception  mission  within  2  months  after  signing  of  the  financing 
agreement  for  tranche  1.  The  mission  will  refine  the  implementation  plan  and  facility 
administration manual. The Government will cause the EAs, though the PMO director, to submit 
to ADB quarterly progress reports within 2 weeks of the end of that quarter, and semiannual 
performance and monitoring reports. ADB will review quarterly and semiannually reports during 
its program annual reviews. Regular reviews will be carried out after tranche effectiveness. A 
midterm review will be undertaken within 4 years after signing of the FFA. It will focus on the 
engineering,  institutional  effectiveness,  results,  environmental  and  social  safeguards, 
compliance with loan covenants, and compliance with the undertakings set out in the FFA. The 
review will allow for any necessary corrections. The EAs will submit a project completion report 
within 3 months of the completion of each project. 
 
66.  ADB  staff  in  headquarters  and  Afghanistan  Resident  Mission  will  monitor  the 
implementation of the Investment Program on a joint venture basis and as a team. Additional 
staff is being deployed to Kabul to work on each of the priority sector Investment Programs: 
energy, transport, and irrigation. The team will review the Investment Program regularly. An 
annual report on the Investment Program will be produced. This will cover issues related to 
each  of  the  components  and  will  report  on  inputs  and  outputs,  and  will  start  generating 
information for outcome and impact indicators in the DMF. All compliance matters will be 
covered under the review, including warranties and representations, covenants, and adherence 
to ADB policies and procedures. Any changes to the tranches will be captured through these 
reports. These tranches have tentative investment and financing plans, which will be updated 
and included in the annual MFF report or on other reports due under the review process. The 
project performance report will be updated every month and reported to the front office of the 
Central  and  West  Asia  Department.  The  front  office  will  call  for  corrective  actions  as 
appropriate.  
 
IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
67.  The intention of the MFF is that the investments will benefit people and businesses, 
thereby contributing to economic growth and prosperity. Energy security is a huge problem in 
Afghanistan. The main benefits accruing from the investment are tangible; others are not. Some 
are physical; others are institutional in nature. Some will be more immediate, while others will be 
long term. Benefits under subsequent tranches will be reported under each PFR and reported 
annually in the summary MFF report. 
 
A.  Financial and Economic Benefits 
 
68.  Financial.  A  financial  analysis  for  the  tranche  1  project  has  been  carried  out  in 
accordance with ADB’s Financial Management and Analysis of Projects (2005). All financial 
costs and benefits have been expressed in 2008 prices. Cost streams used to determine the 
financial internal rate of return—capital investment, operations and maintenance, insurance 
costs, and taxes—reflect the costs of delivering the estimated benefits. The current tariffs with 
an assumed escalation factor were used to estimate the revenue, while incremental operation 
and maintenance costs were charged for each year. 
 
69.  The financial internal rate of return of 13.5% compares favorably with the estimated 
weighted average cost of capital of 1.20%, indicating financial viability for the project. Financial 
viability was gauged by comparing incremental costs and benefits of “with project” and “without

19
project” scenarios. The incremental benefits arise through the increased evacuation of power. 
Non-quantifiable financial benefits, such as the quality of power supply, were not included in the 
financial evaluation. A summary of the financial analysis is in Appendix 15.  
 
70.  Economic. The proposed investments are least-cost. They are part of Afghanistan’s 
integrated generation and transmission expansion. The economic analysis was based on a 
“time-slice” approach to the transmission and distribution system development plan. Economic 
performance was evaluated by comparing “with project” and “without project” scenarios. As 
individual projects are not stand-alone, they would not yield all their benefits if considered in 
isolation. The Investment Program will ease chronic supply shortages and help demand for 
electric power. The main benefits stem from (i) removing bottlenecks to efficient supply of 
electricity to meet the growing energy needs; (ii) improving efficiency, reliability, and emergency 
security; (iii) evacuating power from neighboring countries’ and new plants; and (iv) reducing 
residential and commercial losses. The economic internal rate of return tranche 1 project is 
21.4%,  (based  on  the  incremental  cost–benefit  streams  associated  with  the  Investment 
Program). A summary of the economic analysis is in Appendix 16.  
 
B.  Social and Poverty Impacts 
 
71.  Social and poverty assessments have been carried out. For several projects, samples 
of up to 21 districts in four regions were taken. These surveys established that, although the 
main use of electricity is for household lighting, people are willing to invest in other appliances, 
and improve living conditions and livelihoods. The Investment Program covers rural and non-
rural areas, and benefits poor people, especially those in remote rural areas not connected to 
the grid. The Investment Program will also make a major difference to people in cities. The 
PMO will refine the final poverty and social analysis for each tranche, in accordance with ADB’s 
Handbook  on  Poverty  and  Social  Analysis.12 The  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social 
strategy is in Appendix 17. External monitors to be engaged by the EAs will closely monitor the 
implementation of this strategy. 
 
C.  Social Safeguards 
 
72.  Land  Acquisition  and  Resettlement.  The  Investment  Program  is  divided  into  four 
tranches, each involving different types of projects and contract modalities. LAR requirements for 
projects under tranches 2–4 cannot be confirmed at this stage, but available information suggests 
that the impacts will be similar to those in tranche 1. A LAR framework was prepared in detail for 
tranche 1 investments, in accordance with ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995) and 
Operations Manual F2 on Involuntary Resettlement. LAR plans for the projects under subsequent 
tranches will be finalized once additional due diligence, and in relevant cases design work, is 
completed. The LAR framework is summarized in Appendix 18. 
  
73.  Tranche 1 projects has been categorized as Category B. Three projects in tranche 1 that 
may involve low-intensity LAR are (i) NEPS 220 kV Transmission Line: Kunduz–Taloqan; (ii) 
Baharak Small Hydropower Plant and Mini-Grid; and (iii) Development of Small Hydropower 
Plants in Badakhshan and Bamyan Provinces (cofinanced by JFPR). LAR plans for projects 
under (i) and (ii) have been prepared in accordance with the Involuntary Resettlement Policy 
and the Operations Manual, and were guided by the handbook on involuntary settlement for the 
                                                 
12 ADB. 2001. Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis. Manila. This has been superseded by (i) ADB. 2007. 
Handbook on Social Analysis, A Working Document. Manila; and (ii) ADB. 2006. Poverty Handbook: Analysis and 
Processes to Support ADB Operations, A Working Document. Manila.

20    
first and second projects. Since the specific sites (up to four) for the project under (iii) are to be 
identified during implementation, LAR plans will be prepared for subprojects involving LAR, 
approved by ADB, and implemented before civil works contractors are mobilized in accordance 
with the LAR framework. Other projects in tranche 1 with physical investments do not involve 
LAR: (i) NEPS Distribution Network – Kunduz; (ii) NEPS Distribution Network – Baghlan; and 
(iii) Sheberghan Gas Fields Rehabilitation.  
 
74.  LAR  for  subsequent  tranche  projects  will  be  categorized  through  the  involuntary 
resettlement categorization form. LAR plans will be prepared in accordance with the Involuntary 
Resettlement Policy and the Operations Manual, and guided by the involuntary resettlement 
handbook for projects categorized as Category A and B, and will be attached to the PFR. 
 
75.  The PMO and contractors will update LAR plans for projects with turnkey contracts 
during  the  detailed  design  stage.  For  projects  adopting  the  conventional  design-bid-build 
modality, the implementation consultants will update them during the preconstruction phase. For 
turnkey projects, the contractor will not be able to start construction until the LAR plan is fully 
implemented. For design-bid-build projects, a civil works contractor will not be mobilized until 
the LAR plan is fully implemented. The PMO will monitor the LAR plans and report to ADB. An 
external monitor will be responsible for issuing a no-objection certificate for the start of civil 
works. The external monitor will also prepare safeguard compliance reports twice a year. 
 
76.  Indigenous Peoples. The tranche 1 project has been classified as Category C. Most 
future tranche projects are expected to be the same in terms of indigenous peoples impact. The 
project areas are inhabited by different ethnic groups. The socioeconomic features and level of 
vulnerability of these people do not fit the traits on which the ADB’s definition of indigenous 
people is based. Indigenous peoples impact of subsequent tranche projects will be categorized 
through the indigenous peoples impact categorization form. Indigenous peoples development 
plan and indigenous peoples development frameworks will be prepared in accordance with 
ADB's Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998) for the projects categorized as Category A. Specific 
action  favorable  to  indigenous  people  will  be  included  in  the  PFR  for  tranche  projects 
categorized  as  Category  B.  Related  plans  such  as  the  gender  plan  or  the  community 
participation plan will be attached to the PFR.  
 
77.  Labor Standards. DABS and MOM will ensure that all contractors (i) comply with all 
applicable labor laws; (ii) comply with ADB’s Core Labor Standards;13 (iii) use their best efforts 
to employ women and local people negatively affected by, or living in the vicinity of, the 
projects; (iv) disseminate information at worksites on the risks of sexually transmitted diseases 
and HIV/AIDS for those employed during construction; (v) are required not to differentiate 
between men’s and women’s wages or benefits for work of equal value; and (vi) abstain from 
using child labor. Contractors will ensure that the safety of workers will be in accordance with 
best international practices. The PMO will be responsible for monitoring and reporting labor 
practices to the Government and ADB.  
 
D.  Environmental Impact 
 
78.  The majority of projects under the Investment Program are expected to be classified as 
category  B.  However,  some  projects  could  be  classified  differently.  If  that  occurs,  ADB’s 
environmental policies and procedures will apply. Tranches 2–4 projects require further due 
diligence. The current project list is fairly firm, but some changes could take place over the 
                                                 
13 ADB. 2006. Core Labor Standards Handbook. Manila.

21
Investment Program period. Tranche 1 project has been subjected to detailed due diligence, 
and has been classified as Category B in terms of environmental impact. Tranche 1 projects 
involving physical investment are: (i) NEPS 220 kV Transmission Line: Kunduz–Taloqan; (ii) 
NEPS Distribution Network: Kunduz; (iii) NEPS Distribution Network: Baghlan; (iv) Baharak 
Small  Hydropower  Plant  and  Mini-Grid;  (v)  Development  of  Mini  Hydropower  Plants  in 
Badakhshan and Bamyan Provinces (cofinanced by JFPR); and (vi) Sheberghan Gas Fields 
Rehabilitation. IEE reports for all projects except for the JFPR-cofinanced project have been 
prepared in accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy (2002). Because the final sites (up to 
four) for the JFPR cofinance projects are to be formalized, IEEs will be prepared and approved 
by ADB in accordance with the EARF for these projects before the mobilization of civil works 
contractors.  
 
79.  The contractors will update IEEs for projects with turnkey contracts during detailed design 
stage. For the projects adopting design-bid-build modality, the PMO will update them during the 
preconstruction phase. For turnkey projects, the contractor will not be able to start construction until 
the IEE is approved by ADB. For design-bid-build projects, civil works contractors will not be 
mobilized until the IEE is approved by ADB. The implementation consultants are responsible for 
monitoring the implementation of the environmental monitoring and management plan attached to 
the IEEs, and to report to the PMO. An external monitor will be engaged to perform environmental 
audits twice a year and prepare safeguard compliance reports. 
 
80.  Environmental impacts under all subsequent tranche projects will be categorized through 
the environmental categorization form and supported by rapid environmental assessments. 
Environmental impact examination reports will be prepared in accordance with the Environment 
Policy for projects categorized as Category A and B (sensitive). In accordance with the same 
policy,  IEE  reports  will  be  prepared  for  projects  categorized  as  Category  B.  These 
environmental safeguard documents will be attached to the PFR. 
 
E.  Risks and Assumptions 
 
81.  Assumptions. The Investment Program is based on the following key assumptions: (i) 
successful  and  timely  implementation  of  energy  sector  projects;  (ii)  institutional  capacity, 
including efficiency improvements in DABS; and (iii) continued strengthening of sector reforms, 
better regulation, institutional change, and a sound tariff regime. The transaction team has taken 
into account the experiences of earlier projects. The implementation arrangements put in place 
mitigate many of the issues prevalent in the current portfolio. The establishment of the PMO 
(properly managed and funded, independent and with a clear mandate) assumes a tightening of 
project performance and quality at entry for new investments under all tranches.  
 
82.  Risks. The key risks to the Investment Program include (i) delayed restructuring of 
DABS operations, (ii) insufficient power imports from neighboring countries, (iii) reversal of the 
policy directions, (iv) inadequate project management, and (v) continued security risk. 
 
83.  The  restructuring  of  DABS  is  on  course,  although  the  process  will  need  continued 
political  commitment  and  expertise,  and  working  capital  financing  in  the  short  term. 
Considerable technical assistance is being assigned to this task, including from ADB and other 
agencies  such  as  the  World  Bank.  The  development  of  alternative  power  interconnection 
infrastructure is being supported by an ongoing ADB loan, while the conclusion of a PPA is 
being facilitated. 
84.  Electricity supplies from Uzbekistan are not confirmed, although considerable progress was 
made on this in 2008. Supplies from Tajikistan will come on stream in about 18 months, but only

22    
between May and August. Electricity supplies from Turkmenistan are not yet formalized, and the 
gas project (to supply Pakistan and India) is only on the drawing board. The Central Asia-South 
Asia Regional Electricity Market Project is still in the planning stage and will take time before 
supplies reach Afghanistan. As such, Afghanistan urgently needs to have its own energy strategy 
and investments. Kabul receives only 2–3 hours of electricity a day. 
 
85.  The reversal of policy directions is unlikely but always possible. Afghanistan needs to 
develop energy supplies urgently. Only by following best practices, including a constructive 
policy framework, will Afghanistan be able to attract international financing. The policy needs 
refinements, but it is unlikely to be reversed. The MFF includes this as a condition. 
 
86.  Project management has been a problem. Capacity is lacking, and the systems and 
procedures are inefficient and slow. The establishment of the PMO is an attempt to break with 
past practices, taking a holistic view of the management of project tasks, themes, and reporting. 
Security is likely to remain the most difficult problem in the short to medium term. The situation 
seems to be deteriorating  and this will make it difficult to attract investors and contractors, and 
to implement projects. The MFF calls for the establishment of community-based, small-scale 
investments and contingency finance to deliver basic services in program areas. This will not 
address the core cause of the problem, but it might reduce the risk to program contractors.  
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
A.  Specific Undertakings 
 
87.  The Government and the EAs have agreed to the following specific undertakings, in 
addition to the standard undertakings agreed to in the FFA, which will be incorporated in the 
legal documents.  
 
88.  Policy  Dialogue.  The  Government  will  keep  ADB  informed  about  its  policies  and 
projects related to the energy sector that will materially affect the financial viability of each 
project under the Investment Program, and in particular the power generation and transmission 
policies, laws, and regulations. 
 
89.  Restructuring. A separate business unit other than DABS (TransCo) will own and 
operate high-voltage (110kV and above) power transmission assets and related switchyards 
and substations by January 2013. A regulatory performance-based contract for TransCo will be 
developed and approved by MEW within 3 years. 
 
90.  Tariff. The tariff formulated for TransCo will be adequate to cover its operating costs, 
maintenance, depreciation, and financing cost, and to allow an acceptable return on the equity 
of DABS. Afghanistan will ensure that such tariff is effective by January 2013. The Government 
will ensure that DABS and TransCo have adequate legal powers and enforcement mechanisms 
to effectively collect service fees and penalize defaulters in order to improve the collection 
efficiency, deter non-payment and ensure sustainability of DABS and TransCo’s operations. 
 
91.  Interconnection. Prior to interconnection of the project assets financed under the MFF 
with the Central Asian Power System (CAPS), TransCo will have adopted GOST14 13109-97 (grid 
code) as such is applicable to operation and maintenance of high-voltage power transmission 
assets within CAPS. No interconnection with power producers that involves cross-border power 
                                                 
14 GOST = gosudarstvennyy standart (state standard).

23
transmission will occur until after a long-term PPA on terms and conditions commercially viable for 
DABS is signed by respective parties. 
 
92.  Project Selection Criteria. All projects to be financed under the MFF are selected in 
accordance with the agreed criteria set out in the FFA, which adhere to the relevant requirements of 
the power transmission investment plan and other applicable guidelines for project implementation. 
DABS will monitor the implementation to ensure their successful and timely completion. 
 
93.  Capacity Development. The Government will ensure that key managerial positions on 
projects financed under the MFF are competitively selected and remunerated, free and clear of any 
restrictions applicable to Afghanistan’s public servants. 
 
94.  Auditing  and  Accounting.  The  EAs  will  ensure  that  separate  project  accounts  and 
records are maintained in a timely manner to adequately identify the use of tranche proceeds in 
such a manner and details as may be specified in each financing agreement for relevant tranches. 
Audited financial reports of MFF-financed activities will be submitted to ADB within 6 months of  the 
end of each fiscal year. 
 
95.  Financial Governance. The EAs will ensure that its internal controls are in accordance 
with  the  National  Accounting  Standards  and  an  independent  and  autonomous  internal  audit 
department will be set up in DABS. DABS financial statements shall be audited annually in 
accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards by an external auditor acceptable to 
ADB. 
 
96.  Environment. The EAs will ensure that (i) the projects are designed, constructed, and 
operated in accordance with national and local environmental procedures and guidelines and 
with ADB’s Environment Policy; (ii) the projects are designed, constructed, and operated in 
accordance with the EMPs as reflected in the IEEs and EAR framework; (iii) the environmental 
management and monitoring plan will be incorporated in bidding documents and civil work 
contracts and implemented; and (iv) environmental performance reports will be submitted to 
ADB twice annually during the construction period, including progress made on the mitigation 
measures, monitoring data, problems encountered, enforcement plan, and any violations. 
 
97.  Land  Acquisition  and  Resettlement.  The  EAs  will  ensure  that  the  design, 
implementation and operation of the Investment Program are carried out in accordance with 
ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement (1995), applicable law and government regulations 
in Afghanistan, and the agreed LAR Framework. In the preparation and implementation of 
projects or projects to be financed under the MFF the EAs ensure that (i) all land and rights-
of-way required are made available in a timely manner; (ii) traditional (non-turnkey) civil 
works contractors are mobilized only at the condition that LAR plan approved by ADB is 
disclosed to the affected people (AP) and implemented; (iii) for all projects, independently 
from contract type, civil works will start only after ADB provides no objection and the relevant 
LAR plans are prepared, approved by ADB, disclosed to the APs and implemented; (iv) 
contractors’ activities are in compliance with requirements of the LAR plans; and (v) an 
independent monitor acceptable to ADB is engaged to carry out monitoring and evaluation 
and report to ADB based on the requirements of the LAR plans. 
 
98.  Execution of Civil Works Contracts. The EAs will ensure that, subsequent to award of 
civil works contract under any project, no section or part thereof under the civil works contract will 
be handed over to the contractor unless the applicable provisions of the LAR framework and  
plans, including the timely delivery of compensation to APs, indigenous peoples development

24    
framework  and  indigenous  peoples  development  plans,  and  the  EARF  and  environmental 
management and monitoring plans have been complied with. Any changes to the location, route, 
alignment, or environment impacts on account of detailed designs of related projects will be subject 
to prior approval by ADB or related agency in accordance with the project selection criteria and 
procedures specified in the FFA. Prior to the commencement of civil works, an accredited demining 
agency must have certified that the relevant construction site(s) has been cleared. 
 
99.  Social Impacts. 
 
(i)  Gender. The EAs will follow the principles of the ADB’s policy on gender and 
development  during  the  implementation  of  each  project,  including  taking  all 
necessary actions to encourage women living in the project area to participate in 
planning  and  implementing  project  activities.  The  EAs  will  monitor  the  project 
effects on women through, where relevant, gender-disaggregated data collected 
pursuant  to  the  monitoring  and  evaluation  system  referred  to  in  the  project 
performance monitoring system. 
 
(ii)  Sexually transmitted diseases and HIV/AIDS. With assistance of relevant local 
authorities, the EAs will cause contractors to distribute information on the risks of 
sexually transmitted diseases to those employed during the implementation of 
each project. 
 
(iii)  Women  and  child  labor. The EAs will ensure that (i) there is no differential 
payment between men and women for work of equal value, and (ii) civil works 
contractors do not employ child labor in construction and maintenance activities in 
accordance with applicable laws and regulations and international conventions. 
 
100.  Security. The Government will ensure that its armed forces and police provide in project 
areas protection required for uninterrupted implementation of each project financed under the 
MFF. In addition, it is required that service and works providers in each project submit security 
plans and budgets that would ensure uninterrupted implementation of their respective project 
activities, and include them as part of the contracts and contract price.  
 
101.  Corporate Governance. The Government will ensure that no person serving on the 
board of DABS, TransCo, an electricity distribution company, or a power generation company is 
concurrently a board member of any other entity. 
 
B.  Conditions for Tranche Effectiveness 
 
1.  Conditions for the First Tranche 
102.  A  subsidiary  loan  agreement  between  the  Government  and  DABS  is  in  form  and 
substance satisfactory to ADB, has been duly executed and become effective. 
 
2.  Conditions for the Subsequent Tranches 
103.  Tariff.  DABS has submitted petitions for tariff revisions, as required, to maintain their 
financial viability. Following a tariff determination by MEW or the regulation authority in place, the 
Government will notify such tariff determination in a prompt manner through the official gazette. 
The Government will ensure that the tariffs determined allow for adequately cover their operating 
costs, maintenance, depreciation, and financing, and allow an acceptable return on equity.

25
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
104.  I am satisfied that the proposed multitranche financing facility would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the 
President,  under  the  provisions  of  Article  35.1  of  the  Articles  of  Agreement  of  ADB,  I 
recommend that the Board approve 
 
(i)  the provision of grants and/or loans under the multitranche financing facility in an 
aggregate principal amount not exceeding $570,000,000 equivalent to the Islamic 
Republic of Afghanistan for the Energy Sector Development Investment Program 
from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources  on  such  terms  and  conditions  to  be 
determined in accordance with then applicable policies relating to allocation of and 
eligibility for such resources, and as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in the Framework Financing Agreement presented to the Board; and  
 
(ii)  the administration by ADB of a grant not exceeding $12,000,000 to the Islamic 
Republic of Afghanistan for Development of Mini-Hydropower Plants in Badakhshan 
and Bamyan Provinces to be provided by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction.

36   Appendix 3 
ENERGY SECTOR STRATEGY AND INVESTMENT PLAN 
 
A.  Overview 
 
1.  The  Afghan  energy  strategy  contains  an  implicit  prioritization  of  energy  subsector 
activities. Electricity is prioritized over other sectors. The strategy is based on a four-prong 
approach: 
 
(i)  Greater efficiency from existing operations. It is easier, faster, and cheaper to 
gain a megawatt of power from increasing efficiency than from building a new 
generation plant. Moreover, addressing end-use efficiency now reduces overall 
costs. For every $5 the Government spends in providing compact florescent light 
bulbs, it saves $51 and 49 watts. 
(ii)  Improvement in sector governance and coordination, and the promotion of 
public–private partnerships. The success of the energy sector will depend on 
energy utilities operating independently and mobilizing private sector investment. 
A multisector regulator would be a good start. The aim is to pursue outsourcing,  
preparing an enabling legal, policy, and regulatory base for business, and the 
commercialization of state-owned enterprises (SOEs). In addition, coordination 
among the entities and aid agencies must be strengthened. To accomplish this, 
capacity must be improved. 
(iii)  Rural  energy.  Most  rural  areas  lack  electricity.  This  affects  most  of  the 
population. 
(iv)  Investments  in  new  capacity. Progress in creating new supplies has been 
insufficient. The Government wants to increase production from various sources, 
including hydro, gas, and coal. New supplies must be rationalized, and efforts 
must be focused on a few large projects, such as the North East Power System 
(NEPS). 
 
2.  In addition to addressing immediate and short-term needs, the country also needs to 
consider longer-term issues. Because Afghanistan is building its energy infrastructure from the 
ground up, it can learn from the lessons in other countries. It can prioritize energy efficiency and 
renewable energy. While the national grid is important in transporting power from cheaper 
markets, decentralized power will prove more beneficial in the long run. By locating power 
generation closer to users, losses can be significantly reduced.  
 
B.  Actions Under the Strategy 
 
1.  Increased Efficiency from Existing Operation. 
 
3.  A  key  objective  of  the  strategy  is  to  add  850,000  residential  and  nonresidential 
connections by 2010. This will increase access from 27% to 65% of total population in urban 
areas and from 6% to almost 25% nationally. By 2015, the goal is to increase urban access to 
90% and overall national access to 33%. This work will require the rehabilitation of the system, 
including substations and transformers, and distribution networks. 
 
4.  Existing  generation  facilities,  including  hydropower  and  thermal  plants,  require 
immediate reconstruction. Small diesel generating sets need to be purchased to supplement he 
power supply in selected urban areas, and micro hydro and other energy resources need to be 
developed in rural areas. Through these combined efforts, the supply of electricity throughout 
the country should increase by 66%.

Appendix 3  37
 
5.  Technical Operations. The electricity system is technically deficient. Investments are 
needed  in  the  dispatch  system,  the  controls,  reactive  power,  and  technical  codes  need 
improvement. 
 
6.  Energy Efficiency. The use of efficient lighting, installation of motion detectors, the use 
of better light bulbs, and greater public awareness are some areas for efficiency improvements.  
 
7.  Regional Energy. In the short term, maximizing the use and performance of existing 
assets includes increasing the domestic load to support cross-border power deals. This will 
improve energy security while working on domestic supplies. 
 
2.  Sector Governance, Coordination, and Public–Private Partnerships 
 
a.  Governance 
 
8.  Commercialization. One of the most important activities is to transform SOEs into 
corporate  entities  operating  under  commercial  principles  independent  from  the  overseeing 
ministries, while changing the ministries’ mandate from operating utilities into regulators and 
facilitators. 
 
9.  Afghanistan Electricity Organization (DABM) is undergoing such a transformation. An 
audit of DABM assets, liabilities, and employees has been conducted. Liquidation of DABM is 
expected to be completed by March 2009. On 17 March 2008, the Cabinet approved the articles 
of incorporation for Afghanistan Electricity Corporation (DABS), which will convert it into a 
Government-owned commercial company that will operate under the Commercial Code. Viable 
assets and technically qualified employees of DABM will be transferred to DABS by the end of 
2008.  
 
10.  The  strategy  to  commercialize  power  operations  includes  the  following:  (i)  a  new 
organization at DABS, including a board of directors and senior management group comprising 
a chief executive and financial, operational, and commercial officers; (ii) consolidation of the 19 
corporate offices into eight ”hubs,” which will be converted into profit centers; (iii) installation of 
metering, billing, and collection systems; management information systems; and accounting and 
procurement systems; (iv) regularized internal and independent external audit functions; and (v) 
establishment of new departments including legal, customer service, and loss reduction. 
 
11.  Divestments.  The  Government  has  designed  a  divestment  strategy  calling  for  the 
liquidation, restructuring, corporatization, and/or privatization of other energy assets under state 
control. This process will start in 2009. 
 
12.  The Water and Power Engineering Authority and the Power Construction Unit have been 
approached by private investors. Bringing the Power Construction Unit operations under DABS 
is being considered. 
 
13.  Northern  and  Sabzak  coal  enterprises  have  been  leased  through  management 
contracts. A review is under way to determine how these and other hydrocarbon assets may be 
operated better in the future. 
 
14.  Governance. The complexity of the institutional framework contributes to difficulties in 
developing an effective strategy for the sector, and implementing and monitoring rehabilitation

38   Appendix 3 
works and reforms. Functions within ministries need to be combined and streamlined, with the 
goal of reducing the Government’s direct involvement in the sector.  
 
15.  Financial Discipline. Market-based operations are new to Afghan energy managers. As 
part of the strategy, the Government will seek support from its development partners to improve 
financial management. This requires designing and preparing an integrated annual energy 
budget based on Government support that is in line with the strategic priorities. In addition, new 
protocols for budget management and oversight need to be put in place in the Ministry of 
Finance and the energy ministries.1 The Government will build near-term capacity in accounting, 
project finance, audit, and fiscal performance.  
 
16.  Legal and Regulatory Frameworks. The legal and regulatory frameworks are weak 
and need strengthening. Despite the approval of the Minerals Law in 2005, the legal foundation 
is  inadequate  to  support  legitimate  private  investment,  protect  consumers,  and  ensure 
transparent spending. The Government needs support in this area. Some regulatory work is 
under  way,  but  progress  has  been  slow  and  uncoordinated.  This  matter  requires  a  more 
systematic approach to longer-term sector reform. 
 
17.  Capacity. Capacity development initially should focus on four areas: 
 
(i)  Technical.  Antiquated  systems  require  modernization.  Greater  capacity  is 
needed to operate new high-voltage transmission lines, and to explore oil and 
gas fields. Renewable and coal technologies that ensure safe, clean operations 
are required. Health and safety have received little attention, and enforcement 
and inspection are weak. 
(ii)  Commercial. Institutions need to be made more commercially oriented, and to 
introduce cost-recovery actions at the level of the institutions. 
(iii)  Legal  and  regulatory. The courts, local energy enterprises, and the energy 
ministries,  Ministry  of  Justice  and  Ministry  of  Finance  need  training  on 
commercial matters. 
 
b.  Coordination 
 
18.  Coordination is lacking at two levels: (i) within the Government, and (ii) between the 
Government and the development partners. The strategy calls for improvements in both areas. 
 
19.  Consolidation of Government Energy Functions. Energy functions are spread across 
five ministries, with inputs from three other ministries as well as various national programs. This 
makes coordinating energy strategy difficult. A strategic move would be to establish one Ministry 
of Energy. 
 
20.  Coordination  between  the  Government  and  Development  Partners.  The  Inter-
Ministerial Commission for Energy (ICE) was established in 2006 as the coordinating and 
policy-making body for energy activities. Chaired by the Ministry of Economy, ICE includes the 
ministries of Energy and Water, Finance, and Mines as core members. ICE was designed to 
help  the  Government  understand  and  monitor  energy  development  based  on  commercial 
principles. It oversees energy sector policy and infrastructure investments, and coordinates with 
development partners. ICE brings together a wide array of interests from the Government and 
                                                 
1  Ministry of Energy and Water, Ministry of Mines, Ministry of Rural Rehabilitation and Development, Ministry of Commerce and 
Industries, Ministry of Urban Planning, and Ministry of Agriculture.

Appendix 3  39
its development partners. It is not responsible for project implementation, but it develops policy 
in line with fiscal and investment strategies. It also assists the Government with agreements 
with the private sector. 
 
c.  Privatization 
 
21.  Private  Sector  in  the  Afghan  Energy  Sector.  The  Government  has  paid  limited 
attention to the role of private investment. While the commercialization of the state power 
company (DABM) has started, the restructuring does not include the 66 DABM operations within 
the 19 regional DABM offices. 
 
22.  Independent Power Production. While there is ample evidence of small diesel and 
hydropower  generation  throughout  the  country,  large  viable  independent  or  private  power 
projects have not been restructured. The Government has not explored build-own-operate, 
build- operate-transfer, or other traditional power sector models. 
 
23.  Outsourcing. Outsourcing of power sector functions to the private sector has been 
slow. Services including operations and maintenance, spare parts supply, fuel procurement, 
billing and accounting, and technical management could be contracted out. 
 
24.  Concessions.  In  the  absence  of  the  final  hydrocarbons  law  and  regulations,  the 
Government  supports  contracting  through  concessions.  Mobilizing  these  types  of  contracts 
through transparent tender processes will be emphasized more in the coming years. This 
approach is needed to deal with oil, natural gas, and coal resources. 
 
3.  Rural Energy 
 
25.  Rural energy development is an integral part of the strategy. The approach is to develop 
off-grid and on-grid generation capacity, and to link this to consumers through new investments 
in transmission. 
 
4.  Investment in New Capacity  
 
26.  Generation.  The  domestic  generation  agenda  included  developing  hydropower  and 
thermal power, including gas and coal. 
 
27.  Transmission. The country needs at least three new high-voltage power transmission 
lines to evacuate imported power and to encourage domestic production. Many parts of the 
country lack coverage. 
 
28.  Distribution. The priority is to improve the system in Kabul. This includes technical 
rehabilitation of existing power lines, development of loss-reduction programs, installation of 
technically sound meters, meter reading protocols, and better billing and collection.  
 
29.  Expansion and Synchronization of the Grid. Isolated grids need to become integrated 
into the national grid. With the importation of more power supplies, the synchronization of the 
Afghan grid with its northern neighbors’ grids is vital. This will require investments. 
 
30.  Small-Scale Power. About 80% of the Afghan people live in rural and remote locations. 
The  National  Solidarity  Program  (NSP),  led  by  the  Ministry  of  Rural  Rehabilitation  and

40   Appendix 3 
Development (MRRD), is supporting more use of micro hydropower, solar, and wind energy, 
where possible. The Government is committed to commercializing these activities. 
 
31.  Assessments on New Energy Sources and Uses. Since 2003, several project-based 
feasibility studies have been conducted. These need to be updated.  
 
5.  Implementation  
 
32.  To achieve the objectives and strategic priorities set forth in the energy strategy, the 
medium-term investment plan totals $4.2 billion.

Appendix 5  45 
 
DESCRIPTIONS OF PHYSICAL AND NONPHYSICAL OUTPUTS 
 
A.  Physical Outputs of Tranche 1 
  
1.  The following is the Physical outputs of each project in Tranche 1 are provided below. 
 
(i)  North  East  Power  System  (NEPS)  220  kV  transmission  line:  Kunduz–
Taloqan  Project.  The  project  is  classified  as  category  B  in  terms  of 
environmental impact, and an initial environmental examination (IEE) report has 
been  prepared.  The  project  involves  low-intensity  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement (LAR), and a LAR plan has been prepared. The project entails the 
construction of a double-circuit (single circuit stringing), 220 kV transmission line, 
about 67 kilometers in length, linking the cities of Kunduz and Taloqan. The 
construction of the grid substation at Taloqan is included in an ongoing Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) project.1 
 
(ii)  NEPS  distribution  network:  Kunduz  Project.  The  project  is  classified  as 
category  B  in  terms  of  environmental  impact,  and  IEE  reports  have  been 
prepared.  The  project  does  not  involve  LAR.  The  project  comprises  the 
development and reconstruction of the 20 kV network and rehabilitation of low-
voltage  networks.  Beneficiaries  include  37,000  households,  2,000  small 
businesses and commercial enterprises, and about 135 government or public 
institutions, such as offices, mosques, schools, and dispensaries. In addition, 
several large- or medium-scale industries are operating in Kunduz.  
 
(iii)  NEPS  distribution  network:  Baghlan  Project.  The  project  is  classified  as 
category  B  in  terms  of  environmental  impact,  and  IEE  reports  have  been 
prepared. The project does not involve LAR. The project comprises development 
and  reconstruction  of  the  20  kV  network  and  rehabilitation  of  low-voltage 
networks.  Beneficiaries  include  22,000  households  and  about  1,500  small 
businesses. The construction of grid substations for both cities is cofinanced 
by the Islamic Development Bank for an ongoing ADB project.2  
 
(iv)  Baharak  small  hydropower  plant  and  mini-grid  Project.  The  project  is 
classified as category B in terms of environmental impact, and an IEE report has 
been  prepared.  The  project  involves  some  LAR,  and  a  LAR  plan  has  been 
prepared. The project entails the development of a run-of-river small hydropower 
plant of 2.1 MW on the Warduj River near the city of Baharak in Badakhshan 
Province. The project includes the development of a mini-grid to serve about 
7,500 customers in Baharak and Jurm districts who are not expected to be 
supplied  by  the  NEPS  in  the  foreseeable  future.  The  project  was  prepared 
through ADB technical assistance.3

(v)  Sheberghan Gas Fields Rehabilitation Project. The project is classified as 
category  B  in  terms  of  environmental  impact,  and  an  IEE  report  has  been 
prepared. The project does not involve LAR. The project will rehabilitate the 
dilapidated gas wells to enable extraction of domestic gas to power future gas-
fired power generation that will connect to the NEPS system at Sheberghan. 
 
(vi)  Development  of  mini  hydropower  plants  in  Badakhshan  and  Bamyan 
provinces. The project is classified as category B in terms of environmental 
impact, and an IEE report has been prepared. The project may involve LAR. As 
the specific sites are to be identified during implementation, a LAR framework 
has been prepared to serve as a guide to prepare LAR plans when required. 
However, a priority criterion for site selection is the avoidance of LAR. The 
project entails the development of up to four mini hydropower plants through 
cofinancing by Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction. The project will serve remote 
district centers in Badakhshan and Bamyan provinces, which are not expected to 
be supplied by the NEPS in the foreseeable future. The aggregate installed 
capacity will be about 2 MW.  
 
B.  Nonphysical Outputs of Tranche 1 
   
2.  Non-physical outputs of tranche 1 are provided below. 
 
(i)  NEPS 220 kV system operation and maintenance. The project is a consulting 
service to assist with the maintenance of the newly constructed 220 kV NEPS as 
Afghanistan  Electricity  Corporation  does  not  have  the  technical  capacity  to 
maintain such a system. The contract period will be 3 years, during which DABS 
will undergo intensive training to enhance its capacity to independently operate 
the system by the end of the contract period. The contract will include an option 
for a 2-year extension in case the required capacity is not obtained in the initial 
contract  period.  The  consulting  service  also  includes  identification  and 
procurement of the required tools and spare parts for the maintenance of the 220 
kV NEPS, including emergency restoration systems. 
 
(ii)  Project management. Recognizing the weak project management capacity of 
executing  agencies,  consultants  will  be  recruited  to  support  a  program 
management  office  (PMO).  A  management  information  system  will  be 
established in the PMO to improve efficiency, accuracy, and transparency. 
 
(iii)  Preparation of future tranches. The PMO will have a special due diligence 
team  to  prepare  due  diligence  work  in  support  of  projects  evaluated  for 
subsequent tranches.

Appendix 6  47
SUMMARY OF INDICATIVE PROJECTS, TRANCHES 2–4  
 
A.  Tranche 2 Projects 
 
1.  North East Power System (NEPS) 220 kV Transmission Line Replication: Pul-e-
Khumri–Chimtala ($80 million). The project is a 200-kilometer, double-circuit transmission line 
from Pul-e-Khumri to Chimtala (Kabul). The NEPS system already has a transmission line along 
this corridor. However, as Afghanistan Electricity Corporation (DABS) is planning to import 
electricity from Tajikistan and Uzbekistan, and expand the NEPS system to south of Kabul, 
capacity constraints along this corridor will become a bottleneck. Therefore, before any physical 
expansion of NEPS to the south of Kabul, the capacity of this section needs to be augmented. 
 
2.  DABS Institutional Capacity Development ($10 million). This project will assist DABS 
primarily with capacity building for their management information system, a metering program, 
introduction or upgrading of the billing system, and implementing efficiencies in their collection 
system. 
 
3.  Project Management and Due Diligence—Consulting Services ($5 million). The 
project  will  support  the  project  management  office  in  conducting  a  feasibility  study  on 
hydropower and irrigation schemes in the Lower Kokcha River.  
 
4.  NEPS 220 kV Transmission Line: Southern Extension Phase I ($55 million). The 
Government has asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to consider the development of 
infrastructure south of Kabul. Subject to stable security south of Kabul, ADB has agreed in 
principle to consider financing the construction of the transmission line from Kabul to Gardez. In 
phase I, development between Kabul and Pul-e-Alam is envisaged. 
 
B.  Tranche 3 Projects 
 
5.  NEPS  220  kV  Chimtala  160  MVA  Substation  Replication  ($35  million).  The 
substation at Chimtala (Kabul) needs to expand from the current 320 MVA. An additional 160 
MVA is sufficient to remove bottlenecks from the system over the medium term. 
 
6.  Lower Kokcha River Hydropower Plant Phase I ($44 million). The development of 
the Lower Kokcha River hydropower plant has been identified for tranches 3 and 4. Financing 
will be contingent on meeting ADB’s safeguard requirements. 
 
7.  NEPS 220 kV Transmission Line: Southern Extension Phase II ($21 million). In 
phase II, development between Pul-e-Alam and Gardez is envisaged. 
 
C.  Tranche 4 Project 
 
8.  Lower Kokcha River Hydropower Plant Phase II ($156 million). This project will be a 
continuation of phase I. Financing will be contingent on meeting ADB’s safeguard requirements.

II.  Grant Development Objectives and Expected Key Performance Indicators 
Grant Development Objectives: The Project’s objective is to improve the quality of life of rural 
communities  in  Badakhshan  and  Bamyan  provinces  through  the  provision  of  electricity  services 
supplied by mini hydropower plants (MHP) with generating capacity below 1,000 kilowatts (kW). 
The Project outcome will include: (i) provision of affordable and stable electricity, (ii) increase in rural 
commercial activities from establishment of enterprises using electricity, (iii) increased employment 
opportunities, (iv) reduction of indoor pollution caused by the use of indigenous sources of energy, and 
(v) capacity building in small hydropower development. 
The Project outputs are the identification, planning, designing, and establishment of a maximum of four 
off-grid MHPs, each with an installed capacity in the order of magnitude of 500 kW. Target areas are 
district centers that are not planned for grid connection in the foreseeable future or are being supplied 
through expensive and unreliable diesel generation. Communities will receive support to establish 
income-generating activities during the day-time (i.e., off-peak hours). 
The MHPs will be operated and maintained by the Afghanistan Electricity Corporation (DABS), the 
national  power  utility.  To  ensure  sustainable  management,  capacity  building  is  integrated  as  an 
essential component of the Project. Similarly, the entire project cycle is regarded as an on-the-job 
training opportunity in which counterpart staff of the Executing Agency, DABS, will be closely engaged 
in subproject preparation and implementation.  
Expected Key Performance Indicators (maximum 5 indicators): 
1.  A maximum of four MHPs, each with installed capacity of around 500 kW totaling up to 2.0 MW 
commissioned 
2.  Cheap and reliable electricity supplied to up to 5,000 households (400 watts[W]/household) 
3.  Small enterprises propagated in the supply area 
4.  Capacity  building  of  Ministry  of  Energy  and  Water  (MEW)  and  DABS  staff  in  the 
implementation and operation of MHPs  
5.  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

PROGRAM MANAGEMENT OFFICE ORGANIZATION 
 
 
1.  Front Office. The director will be an International consultant responsible for day-to-day 
operations of program management office (PMO), and will be engaged for at least 5 years 
without interference from the Government. 
 
2.  Technical Team. Its mandates will be to (i) handle all operational and technical matters 
during implementation, (ii) supervise engineering consultants responsible for design work for 
subsequent tranches, (iii) supervise contracts, (iv) provide inputs to the preparation of the 
procurement document, (v) support prequalification and qualification of bidders, and (vi) assist 
with the evaluation of bids. 
 
3.  Legal  Team.  Legal  expertise  may  be  outsourced  to  an  international  law  firm.  Its 
mandates will be to (i) support the preparation of the procurement documents; (ii) manage the 
bid processes; (iii) support the prequalification of contractors and investor award of, as well as 
the bids award; (iv) support the preparation of the contract documents; (v) assist with contract 
variation work; (vi) report to ADB on framework financing agreement undertakings and loan 
covenants; and (vii) oversee general checks and balances on work during implementation, and 
introduce quality control fiduciary oversight. 
 
4.  Finance  and  Administration  Team.  Its  mandate  will  be  administration,  including 
handling withdrawal applications, bank accounts, and payment instructions. 
 
5.  Safeguards and Gender Mainstreaming Team. Its mandates will be to review all new 
project design, and check implementation work. 
 
6.  Due  Diligence  Team.  The  due  diligence  team  will  be  made  up  of  staff  from  the 
technical, legal, finance and administration, and safeguards teams. Its mandate will be the 
preparation of new projects under the multitranche financing facility. 
 
7.  Results Measurement Team. Methodology and measuring to be outsourced to a local 
university or institution. Its mandate will be to measure the results of Asian Development Bank 
projects using a methodology consistent with the design and monitoring framework. 
 
8.  Communications Team. Its mandates will be establishing a strategy and action plan, 
and communicating regularly to the public on actions and successes. 
 
9.  Capacity Building Team. Establishing PMO to establish a team of advisory function to 
help Afghanistan Electricity Corporation (DABS), Ministry of Mines (MOM) and other institutions. 
Its mandates will be to provide training in (i) planning and project management, (ii) financial 
management, (iii) policy refinements, and (iv) business operations (including commercial and 
operational assistance).

7.  General. National competitive bidding for the procurement of goods and related services 
shall conform to the provisions for Open Tender without prequalification as prescribed in the 
Procurement  Law  of  October  2005  and  elaborated  in  the  Rules  of  Procedure  for  Public 
Procurement  issued  by  the  Ministry  of  Finance  in  April  2007,  with  the  clarifications  and 
modifications described in the following paragraphs required for compliance with the provisions 
of the ADB Procurement Guidelines. 
 
8.  Registration and Other Pre-Bid Requirements 
 
(i)  Bidding shall not be restricted to Shortlists or Standing Lists. 
(ii)  No bid shall be declared as ineligible of the grounds of debarment without ADB’s 
prior concurrence. 
(iii)  No bid shall be declared ineligible on the grounds of government regulations that 
restrict sources without ADB’s prior concurrence. 
(iv)  Foreign suppliers and contractors from ADB member countries shall be allowed to 
bid, without registration, licensing, and other government authorizations. However, 
in case these foreign suppliers and contractors are declared winning bidders, the 
requirements  may  be completed after  award  and  before  signing  of  contract, 
without unreasonable costs or additional requirements. 
 
9.  Prequalification.  Post qualification shall be used unless prequalification is explicitly 
provided for in the loan agreement/procurement plan. Irrespective of the procedure applied 
(whether  prequalification  or  post  qualification),  no  domestic  or  foreign  contractor  shall  be 
precluded from participation. 
 
10.  If prequalification is undertaken, the prequalification criteria should include "Eligibility 
Requirements", "Financial Situation", "Pending Litigation", and "Experience". Technical 
Capacity (personnel and equipment) should not be part of the prequalification criteria. 
 
11.  Interested bidders shall be given a minimum period of 28 days for the preparation and 
submission of prequalification applications.

62  Appendix 12 
12.  Advertising. Bidding of NCB contracts estimated at $500,000 or more for goods and 
related  services  and  NCB  contracts  estimated  at  $1,000,000  or  more  for  works  shall  be 
advertised on ADB’s website via the posting of the Procurement Plan. 
 
13.  Bidding  Documents.  Procuring  entities  shall  use  standard  bidding  documents 
acceptable to ADB, based ideally on the standard bidding documents issued by ADB. 
 
14.  Bidding  Period.  Procuring  entities  shall  allow  for  a  minimum  of  four  weeks  for 
submission of bids. 
 
15.  Bid Security. Where required, bid security shall be in the form of a bank guarantee or 
check from a reputable bank and should not be more than two percent of the estimated value 
of contract to be procured. 
 
16.  Preferences. No preference of any kind shall be given shall be given to domestic 
bidders or for domestically manufactured goods.  
 
17.  Evaluation. No bid shall be rejected on the grounds of price, or for any other reason(s) 
not  related  to  the  evaluation  and  qualification  criteria,  without  ADB’s  prior  concurrence. 
Prompt payment discounts offered by bidders shall not be considered in bid evaluation. 
 
18.  Price Negotiations. Price negotiation shall be allowed only after receiving ADB’s prior 
concurrence. 
 
19.  Advance Payments. No advance payment shall be made without an advance payment 
security in the form of a bank guarantee or check from a reputable bank. 
 
20.  Government-Owned Enterprises. Government-owned enterprises in Afghanistan shall 
be  eligible  to  participate  only  if  they  can  establish  that  they  are  legally  and  financially 
autonomous, operate under commercial law, and are not a dependent agency of the procuring 
entity, or the Project Executing Agency, or the Implementing Agency. 
 
21.  Right to Inspect and Audit. A provision shall be included in all NCB works and goods 
contracts financed by the ADB requiring suppliers and contractors to permit ADB to inspect their 
accounts and records and other documents relating to the bid submission and the performance 
of the contract, and to have them audited by auditors appointed by ADB. 
 
22.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
(i)  The Borrower shall reject a proposal for award if it determines that the bidder 
recommended for award has, directly or through an agent, engaged in corrupt, 
fraudulent,  collusive,  or  coercive  practices  in  competing  for  the  contract  in 
question; and 
(ii)  ADB will declare a firm or individual ineligible, either indefinitely or for a stated 
period, to be awarded a contract financed by ADB, if it at any time determines 
that the firm or individual has, directly or through an agent, engaged in corrupt, 
fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices in competing for, or in executing, ADB-
financed  contract,  as  indicated  in  paragraph  1.14  (a)  of  ADB's  Procurement 
Guidelines.

Appendix 12  63
 
23.  Disclosure of Decision on Contract Awards. At the same time that notification of 
award of Contract is given to the successful bidder, the results of bid evaluation shall be 
published in a local newspaper, or well-known freely accessible website identifying the bid and 
lot numbers and providing information on (i) name of each bidder who submitted a Bid, (ii) bid 
prices as read out at bid opening, (iii) name of bidders whose bids were rejected and the 
reasons for their rejection, and (iv) name of the winning bidder, and the price it offered, as well 
as duration and summary scope of the contract awarded. The executing agency/implementing 
agency/contracting  authority  shall  respond  in  writing  to  unsuccessful  bidders  who  seek 
explanations on the grounds on which their bids are not selected. 
 
24.  Member Country Restriction. Bidders must be nationals of member countries of ADB, 
and offered goods, works, and related services must be produced in and supplied from member.

SUMMARY TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 
 
1.  The program management office (PMO) will engage the services of experts to assist with a 
range of tasks. Some of the first mandates are project related and include: 
 
(i)  implementing (a) North East Power System (NEPS) 220-kilovolt (kV) Transmission 
Line: Kunduz–Taloqan Project; and (b) NEPS Distribution Network: Kunduz and 
Baghlan Project; 
(ii)  implementing Baharak Small Hydropower Plant and Mini-Grid Project; 
(iii)  implementing Sheberghan Gas Fields Rehabilitation Project; 
(iv)  supporting NEPS 220 kV Systems Operation and Maintenance Project; and 
(v)  providing PMO support, including project management and project preparation for 
subsequent tranches. 
 
2.  Relevant terms of reference (TORs) have been drafted and summarized in this appendix. 
 
A.  NEPS 220 kV Transmission Line and Distribution Networks Project 
 
3.  The PMO will engage a consultant to prepare conceptual designs and help with the 
procurement of three (or two, depending on the structure) turnkey contracts in accordance with the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). 
The work will also include the development and implementation of a comprehensive project 
management plan to ensure the most efficient, timely, and economical implementation of the 
transmission  and  distribution  network  projects.  This  plan  should  take  into  consideration  the 
engineering  technology  required,  the  resources  and  costs  involved,  and  the  time  frame  for

preliminary designs, preparation of conceptual designs, elaboration of technical specifications, and

the PMO on the optimum number of contract packages. The consultant will also assist the PMO in 
the issuance of bid documents, evaluation of bids, and preparation of bid evaluation reports to be 
submitted to ADB. During the construction phase, the consultant will help with thebe responsible 
for managing contracts, including making recommendations for testing, and commissioning all 
three projects. The duration of the consulting services will be about 36 months.
