D.  NEPS 220 kV Systems Operation and Maintenance Project 
 
8.  Afghanistan Electricity Corporation (DABS) has gained good experience in the operation 
and maintenance (O&M) of its existing 110 kV system, which supplies Kabul. However, DABS 
does  not  have  any  experience  with  the  operation  of  a  220  kV  transmission  system,  or 
contemporary protection and communication systems. Hence, DABS is seeking one contractor to 
manage, operate, and maintain the NEPS 220 kV system for up to 3 years, with two 1-year 
options for providing continued assistance to DABS to operate and maintain the expanding 
system. This consulting service will emphasize training of DABS staff to take over the O&M of the 
system in a phased manner over 3 years. The consultant will also be responsible for assisting 
DABS with the procurement of (i) spare parts, (ii) equipment, (iii) tools, and (iv) emergency 
restoration system, which are to be financed by a separate procurement package under the 
Investment Program.

anticipated positions include (i) project manager, (ii) transmission line manager, (iii) substation 
manager, (iv) procurement specialist, (v) lineman (trainer), (vi) electrician (trainer), and (vii) training 
specialist.

Appendix 15  69
SUMMARY FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The financial analysis of the proposed projects under tranche 1 has been carried out in 
accordance with the Financial Management and Analysis of Projects1 of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB). All financial costs and benefits have been expressed at constant 2008 prices. Cost 
streams used to determine the financial internal rate of return (FIRR)—capital investment, and 
operations and maintenance—reflect the cost of delivering the estimated benefits. The assumed 
tariffs are based on existing tariffs used for the respective projects. 
 
B.  Methodology and Major Assumptions 
2.  The Investment Program involves several projects. Apart from the Baharak Hydro Power 
Plant project, all of the project’s financial benefits are calculated based on the assumption that 
the country’s 220-kilovolt (kV) transmission line system will be in operation and transmitting 
power by the time the projects are completed.  
 
3.  Financial viability was examined by comparing the incremental costs and benefits of 
“with  investment”  and  “without  investment”  scenarios.  The  incremental  benefits  arise  from 
increases  in  power  transmitted  through  the  transmission  and  distribution  system  because 
physical constrains have been removed as a result of the investment. Installing additional 
transmission  and  distribution  infrastructure  removes  the  bottlenecks  that  prevent  available 
generation and import capacity from being transmitted. Incremental operating and maintenance 
costs have been computed as a percentage of the investment. It is assumed that the investment 
will have a 30-year economic life; residual value has not been factored in. 
 
4.  Tariffs are not set by a central agency on a regional basis. Tariffs used in this analysis 
are based on the existing tariffs used in the region of the project, and have been adjusted to a 
level of self sustainability of the project. The demand function for the adjusted tariffs has been 
computed using past studies on demand for electricity in Afghanistan, primarily from technical 
assistance.2  
 
5.  For the operations and maintenance project, which does not generate revenue, no 
benefits were included and an FIRR analysis was not undertaken. Costs from the projects were 
included in the analysis of the overall financial viability of Tranche 1. Detailed information on the 
methodology and assumptions is in Supplementary Appendix B. 
 
C.  Weighted Average Cost of Capital and Financial Internal Rate of Return 
6.  To  compute  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  (WACC),  it  is  assumed  that  the 
financing  sources  would  consist  of  Afghanistan  Electricity  Corporation  (DABS)  equity 
contribution financed through retained earnings. Based on Afghanistan’s long-term depository 
interest  rate,  the  cost  of  DABS’s  equity  is  calculated  at  7%  in  nominal  costs.  The  other 
assumptions  are  a  domestic  inflation  rate  of  8%  and  tax  rate  of  3%.  The  WACC  for  the 
investment program during 2009–2012 is 0.92% (Table A15.1).

SUMMARY ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
1.   Government  is  the  main  investor  in  electricity  transmission  throughout  the  world. 
Investment in power transmission involves large amounts of capital, little maintenance cost, and a 
return over a long period. Government or an independent regulator regulates this sector because 
of its natural monopolistic characteristics—high fixed costs make it unprofitable for a second firm to 
enter and compete. 
 
 2.   All the components are part of the least-cost expansion program developed under the 
power system master plan. The plan considers supply alternatives to areas without grid supply and 
with large-scale isolated diesel generation. The Investment Program is the least-cost option for 
developing transmission and distribution network in the selected cities. Incrementally, the Project 
program  will  greatly  reduce  the  reliance  on  inefficient  and  high-cost  village,  household,  and 
enterprise self-generation at unit costs in the range $0.15–$0.55 per kilowatt-hour (kWh). The 
estimated average incremental cost of grid-connected electricity is $0.079 per kWh. 
 
B.   Economic Cost of Project Components 
 
3.   To convert financial project cost into economic cost, turnover and income taxes were 
deducted, and connection costs were added. Annual operation and maintenance (O&M) and 
administration costs were calculated in economic prices (with financial prices adjusted using the 
standard conversion factor). No price contingencies were included in the base capital cost, but the 
economic  capital  costs  include  physical  contingencies.  Costs  were  separated  into  foreign 
exchange and local costs. A standard conversion factor of 0.9 was used. The cost of supply was 
valued based on the long-run marginal cost for generation and transmission as calculated in the 
power sector master plan. 
 
 4.   As  in  the  financial  analysis,  30  years  was  used  for  the  project  economic  analysis. 
Investment is assumed to take place during 2010–2013, and projects benefits are assumed to be 
realized thereafter. Beyond 2025, further investment will be required to meet incremental demand 
growth. 
 
5.  With regards to the O&M component, Afghanistan Electricity Corporation (DABS), the 
state-owned enterprise responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity in 
Afghanistan,  operates  the  110-kilovolt  (kV)  transmission  system.  However,  DABS  lacks  the 
technical and managerial capacity, as well as the experience, to operate and maintain the more 
complex 220 kV transmission system, and to coordinate the operations with systems dispatched. A 
number of options were considered. Contracting out O&M of the transmission system with a 
capacity  building  program  was  identified  as  the  preferred  option,  because  it  enables  the 
transmission system to become operational immediately after construction is completed. It also 
facilitates the transfer of technical and managerial expertise. Further, it provides a structured 
training program (both classroom and hands-on training) to develop the capacity of DABS staff to 
operate  the  transmission  system  after  the  management  contract  has  expired.  A  detailed 
explanation of the economic analysis of the O&M is in Supplementary Appendix A.  
 
C.  Quantification of Benefits 
 
6.  The main benefits are derived from (i) the eventual connection to northern neighboring 
countries for the long-term reliable electricity; (ii) the connection of new customers to electricity; (iii)

Appendix 16  73
improved availability and reliability; and (iv) the use of non-diesel sources to generate electricity, 
and  loss  reduction.  The  incremental  and  non-incremental  benefits  were  selected  separately. 
Incremental benefits were calculated using customers’ willingness to pay. Non-incremental benefits 
were not captured in the calculation, as resource cost savings for individual components could not 
be reliably estimate.  
  
7.  Most households in the project area do not have access to grid electricity. However, village-
sponsored systems and privately operated generators based on diesel or gas-powered generation 
sets provide limited amounts of electricity. Thus, even in the absence of grid supply, the residential, 
Government, and other sectors consume some electricity, although the price paid is substantially 
higher than for the grid-connected customers. 
   
1.  Domestic Consumers 
 
8.  For the economic analysis, adjustments were made to incremental electricity sales to 
exclude  non-incremental  energy  consumption,  i.e.,  existing  energy  consumption  that  will  be 
captured by Afghanistan Electricity Organization (DABM) as the network is rehabilitated. Based on 
the findings of the socioeconomic survey, the domestic average non-incremental demand was 
estimated at 9.3 kWh per month per household. For other consumer groups, it was assumed that 
suppressed demand is met from other electrical and nonelectrical sources. 
 
9.  The economic benefits of extending the grid supply to unserved areas are estimated based 
on the cost of alternative energy sources used for existing consumption levels, as well as on the 
willingness to pay for induced consumption if a reliable grid supply were available. An analysis of 
the socioeconomic survey showed that that the non-incremental consumption of electricity or its 
equivalent in other forms of energy is approximately $5.80 per household per month, whether grid-
connected or not. Many households with access to electricity are supplied by village-operated gas- 
or  diesel-powered  generation  sets  for  an  average  of  about  5  hours  per  day.  The  average 
expenditure per household from this source is $5.12 per month for consumption of 9.3 kWh, 
equivalent to $0.55 per kWh. 
 
10.  Households in project areas connected to the grid pay a tariff of $0.02–$0.05 per kWh. 
They spend on average $5.86 per month for electricity, consuming 107–281 kWh per household 
per month. Thus, incremental consumption of electricity within the project areas in the domestic 
sector is 98.5–280 kWh per month per household (total average consumption with the project less 
non-incremental consumption). Therefore, non-incremental consumption of electricity is valued at 
the resource cost of $0.55 per kWh. 
 
11.  Incremental consumption of electricity, valued assuming a linear demand function (i.e., that 
50% of the difference between the current tariff and the cost of the alternative represents consumer 
surplus), is estimated at $0.03 per kWh). A semi-log demand function, which would theoretically 
lower the value of the incremental consumption, was not used, because the price change would 
not be significant after rounding to one decimal place in US dollars. 
 
12.  The analysis ignored any benefit from supply reliability improvements because the level of 
industrialization is very low in Afghanistan and, consequently, the difference between the value of 
lost load and tariff  will  be  low.  An average incremental cost  of future electricity supply  was 
estimated as part of the power system master plan to be about $0.09 per kWh for the integrated 
central grid. Most customers in the current and expanded network will be connected at the low-
voltage level. At current tariffs, supply costs are typically under-recovered, and an economic 
subsidy to domestic consumers will be realized as the system expands.

74   Appendix 16 
2.  Operation and Maintenance 
 
13.  Minor benefits to the O&M component have been identified. However, for the purposes of 
calculating the EIRR, it is believed that the net economic benefits of the O&M component are the 
foregone benefits of the other projects without implementation of the component. In other words, 
without the O&M component, DABS would not be able to operate the 220 kV system leading to the 
transmission line remaining idle or producing unreliable and low-quality service. Therefore, the 
component contributes to the project as an “all or nothing” benefit—benefits of the other projects 
would be gained with the inclusion of the O&M component, but none would be gained without it. As 
such, only the costs of the O&M component have been included in the EIRR analysis without 
including any specific benefit coming from the O&M component directly. 
 
3.  Gas Fields Rehabilitation 
 
14.  An  additional  benefit  for  the  Sheberghan  Gas  Fields  Rehabilitation  Project—gas 
purchases by DABS for a future gas-fired power plant—has been factored in. The economic 
benefit of rehabilitating the gas facilities are revenues from the sale of incremental fuel to DABS. 
Production is assumed to start in 2015 with 2.8 million gigajoules (GJ) per year sold, increasing 
to more than 10.0 million GJ in 2030. The gas tariff is conservatively set at $6 per GJ throughout 
the model life. 
 
D.  Economic Model and Evaluation 
 
15.  To test the economic viability of each of the components, the economic internal rate of 
return (EIRR) was calculated based on the incremental cost and benefit streams associated with 
each  project.  The  economic  analysis  evaluated  the  economic  performance  of  the  proposed 
components by comparing the “with project” and “without project” scenarios, i.e., the economic 
value of the incremental and non-incremental supply of electricity that the components will provide 
compared with the existing patterns of energy use in non-electrified areas. 
 
16.  Economic returns are acceptable for most projects. This stems from the capacity of the grid 
extensions to bring urban-quality power at the urban tariff to rural villages that would otherwise face 
high costs for low-quality service. The Baharak hydro power project is 0.5 percentage points below 
the 12% benchmark because of its large loan (about $30 million) for a relatively small generation 
output (2 megawatts) and a small initial service population (35,000). The project is considered 
important  because  the  service  population  is  isolated.  However,  the  facility  will  allow  poor 
households on average to consume more than 10 times the electricity that they had access to with 
a similar household budget without the project. The Sheberghan Gas Fields Rehabilitation Project 
produces a relatively high EIRR because all of the purchases will be used to supply a planned gas-
fired power plant that will supply the national grid with electricity.

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A. Links to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
The Country Strategy and Program Update (2006–2008)a support programs for power transmission and distribution. 
Because  of  the  prolonged  conflict,  creating  livelihood  opportunities  and  stabilizing  economic  life  have  been 
continuing challenges. The country faces a tremendous challenge in increasing and maintaining a stable supply of 
energy. Although the primary focus has been on lighting and heating, a longer-term approach is required if 
electricity is to contribute to sustained economic growth and support poverty reduction efforts. 
 
More than 80% of the population lives in rural and remote areas, where off-grid energy supply is supported through 
the National Solidarity Project (NSP). The Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction component will provide support to this 
sector, while the transmission and distribution component will support urban and/or town supply.  
B.  Poverty Analysis                                Targeting Classification: General intervention 
1. Key Issues  
The continuing state of conflict in Afghanistan has resulted in deteriorating systems for energy transmission and 
distribution nationally. The rural poor particularly have no access to a reliable supply of energy. 
 
Supporting better efficiency of the sector and improving access are expected to ensure a reliable supply to multiple 
users.  Providing  a  stable  supply  of  energy  through  support  for  rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  of  energy 
infrastructure, including institutional development, will help to stimulate the local economy and improve household 
supply.  
 
Projects under the Investment Program will focus on rehabilitation and expansion of existing facilities, including off-
grid rural electrification beyond the main population centers. Additionally, uninterrupted, 24-hour supply is expected 
for eastern and northeastern Afghanistan, as well as district centers not yet connected to the grid. 
 
For the commercial and industrial sectors, which currently use generators or fuelwood, a stable electricity supply is 
considered a key stimulus for rehabilitating now-defunct industry and establishing new ones, such as oil refineries, 
sugar mills, and rice mills. Small-scale businesses are likely to expand when connected to the grid.  
 
The population in the beneficiary areas is growing, and the standard of living of most households is improving. As 
such, a healthy demand for electricity can be expected. Over time, the Investment Program is expected to 
contribute to greater productivity in the industrial and small-scale commercial sectors.  
 
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
The project is expected to directly benefit about 92,000 households, or 1.2 million poor people. The average daily 
per capita income was estimated at $0.39 per day.   
 
The population benefiting from the project is urban- or town-based and rural. The primary occupation is farming, followed 
by government employment. Household’s have multiple sources of income, either through the household head or other 
wage-earning family members.  
 
A stable electricity supply was considered a second priority to clean, potable water by the households surveyed for 
the social assessment. Electricity was perceived to be a strong contributor to better learning opportunities for 
children, generally better livelihoods, and wider access to regular water supply. Fewer health problems resulting 
from the substitution of kerosene with electricity was perceived to be an important benefit. The study found a strong 
willingness to pay, but the agency responsible for payment collections was weak. Of the 1,161 households 
surveyed, 81.6% responded that the current supply was inadequate for their household needs and 62% were willing 
to pay for a grid connection. The poorest households expended a higher share of their income on energy, with 
kerosene being the most common form. Grid-supplied electricity was found to be the cheapest form of electricity 
used by poor households.

Regular  supply  and  access  is  also  expected  to  provide  support  to  the  Disarmament,  Demobilization  and 
Reintegration Program. Ex-combatants who surrender their weapons are retrained and provided with start-up costs 
and supported in forming a business. In addition, the presence of the United Nations, bilateral and nongovernment 
organization programs that also assist in community development initiatives, returning refugees and internally 
displaced persons; reintegration and support to women’s participation in civil and economic activities will all benefit 
from  improved  supply  and  efficiency.  In  small  towns,  small  businesses,  such  as  shops,  restaurants,  agro-
processing, and home-based businesses, are likely to gain the most.

from its previous alignment, which requires a re-estimation of costs. Security issues were discussed, and the region

SUMMARY LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT FRAMEWORK 
A.  Introduction 
1.  Background 
1.  Afghanistan is requesting financial assistance from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
to implement the Energy Sector  Enhancement Investment Program. Afghanistan Electricity 
Corporation (DABS) will be the Executing Agency (EA). Finance will be provided through a 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) comprising discrete projects to be implemented sequentially 
over 5 years, indicatively under three tranches. The Investment Program includes physical and 
nonphysical  projects.  Projects  in  tranche  1  with  physical  investments  that  may  entail  land 
acquisition and resettlement (LAR) include (i) a transmission line from Kunduz to Taloqan, and 
(ii)  the  Baharak  Hydropower  development.  Similar  types  of  projects  are  envisaged  for  the 
subsequent tranches. 
2.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement Plans  
2.  DABS prepared this LAR framework1 to guide the preparation of LAR plans or short LAR 
plans2 for  projects  under  the  Investment  Program  in  a  fashion  fitting  the  requirements  of 
Afghanistan  law  and  ADB's  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy  (1995).  This  LAR  framework 
outlines provisions, procedures, and institutional requirements for preparing and implementing 
LAR plans in projects that require LAR. The program management office (PMO) of DABS, assisted 
by  experts  engaged  through  the  management  and  implementation  consultants,  will  be 
responsible for conducting the social assessment and preparation of LAR plans as per this LAR 
framework. 
 
3.  LAR- Related Project Implementation Conditions 
3.  The initiation of the work for each tranche will be conditioned on the preparation of an 
initial impact assessment identifying likelihood/ and nature of LAR impacts, as well as the LAR 
planning capacity needed for the tranche and projects. Based on this initial assessment, the LAR 
framework may have to be modified to address LAR issues specific to the tranche and projects. 
Once a project design is finished, a due diligence scoping plan subdividing project sections or lots 
between those with and without LAR will be a condition for initiating any civil work in sections 
where LAR is not needed. Finally, the preparation and implementation of a LAR plan acceptable 
to ADB will be a condition to initiate civil works in sections or lots where LAR is required. The draft 
LAR plans based on detailed designs and on completion of the detailed measurement survey 
(DMS).  A full census and inventory of losses will be disclosed in Dari to the affected persons and 
affected families and submitted to ADB for review and approval before the beginning of civil 
works.  Compensation  and  other  assistance  will  be  paid  to  the  affected  persons  before 
construction begins.

C.  Resettlement Principles for the Program 
5.  Based on this analysis of national provisions and ADB policy (Table A18.1), the broad 
resettlement principles for this Investment Program will be the following: 
(i)  Affected person impacts must be avoided or minimized as much as possible. 
(ii)  If impacts are unavoidable, the affected persons will be identified and assisted in 
improving or regaining their standard of living. 
(iii)  Information  on  the  preparation  and  implementation  of  a  LAR  plan  will  be 
disclosed to all affected persons, and people’s participation will be ensured in 
planning and implementation. All LAR plans for the projects with resettlement 
impacts will be disclosed to the affected persons. 
(iv)  Land will be acquired for the project in accordance with the LAL of Afghanistan 
and ADB policy. The LAL specifies adequate compensation for the properties to 
be acquired. Additional support would be extended for meeting the replacement 
value of the property. Affected persons who do not own land or other properties,

Appendix 18  81
but have economic interests or lose their livelihoods, will be assisted according to 
the broad principles described in this document. 
(v)  Before taking possession of the acquired lands and properties, compensation 
and resettlement and rehabilitation (R&R) assistance will be paid in accordance 
with the provision described in the respective resettlement plans. 
(vi)  An  entitlement  matrix  for  different  categories  of  affected  persons  has  been 
prepared  and  provisions  will  be  kept  in  the  budget  for  those  who  were  not 
present at the time of census survey. However, people moving into the project 
area after the cutoff date will not be entitled to any assistance. In case of land 
acquisition, the date of notification for acquisition will be treated as the cutoff 
date. For non-titleholders, such as squatters and encroachers, the date of the 
project census survey or a similar designated date declared by the executing 
agency will be considered the cutoff date. 
(vii)  Appropriate grievance redress mechanisms will be established at the district level 
to ensure speedy resolution of disputes. 
(viii)  All activities related to resettlement planning, implementation, and monitoring 
would ensure the involvement of women and other vulnerable groups. 
(ix)  Consultations with affected persons will continue during the implementation of 
the LAR and rehabilitation.  
 
6.  All  affected  families  and  affected  persons  will  be  entitled  to  a  combination  of 
compensation and resettlement assistance, reflecting the type of asset lost, magnitude of loss, 
general  impact  on  the  affected  person’s  livelihood,  and  degree  of  the  affected  person’s 
socioeconomic vulnerability. The affected persons will be entitled to five types of compensation 
or assistance: (i) compensation for loss of land and crops or trees at replacement value; (ii) 
compensation  for  residential  or  commercial  structures  and  other  immovable  assets  at 
replacement value; (iii) assistance in lieu of the loss of business or wage income; (iv) assistance 
for shifting; and (v) rebuilding and/or restoration of community resources or facilities. 
 
D.  Compensation Eligibility and Entitlements 
7.  This LAR framework and resettlement procedural guidelines will apply to all projects 
under the Investment Program. This will ensure that all persons affected by the acquisition of 
land and other fixed assets, by change in the use of land, and by the restrictions imposed by 
project activities on land use, will get appropriate compensation and rehabilitation assistance.  
 
1.  Eligibility 
8.  Affected persons entitled to compensation, or at least rehabilitation provisions under the 
Project, are 
(i)  all persons losing land with or without title, formal land-use rights, or traditional 
land-use rights; 
(ii)  tenants whether registered or not; 
(iii)  owners of buildings, crops, plants, or other objects attached to the land; and 
(iv)  persons losing business, income, and salaries. 
 
9.  Compensation eligibility will be limited by a cutoff date to be set at the end of the impacts 
assessment  and  affected  family/affected  person  census  carried  out  immediately  after  the 
conclusion of the detailed design. All affected families or affected persons who settle in affected 
areas after this date, and who cannot prove that they are displaced users of affected plots, will 
not be eligible for compensation. DABS will inform local communities regarding the cutoff date

82   Appendix 18 
through their local offices and through the relevant local government agencies. However, they 
will be given sufficient advance notice to vacate premises or dismantle affected structures 
before project implementation. Their dismantled structures will not be confiscated and they will 
not pay fines or sanctions.  
 
2.  Entitlements 
10.  Entitlement  provisions  for  affected  persons  losing  land,  houses,  and  income  and 
rehabilitation subsidies will include provisions for permanent and temporary land losses, house 
and buildings losses, crops and trees losses, a relocation subsidy, and a business losses 
allowance based on tax declarations and/or lump sums. These entitlements are detailed as 
follows: 
(i)  Permanent loss of agricultural land will be compensated at replacement cost based 
on market rates. DABS will pay costs for documentary stamps and registration. 
Affected persons losing more than 10% of their land will be considered severely 
affected and will receive an additional 1 year crop compensation quota or alternate 
land based on availability and in consultation with the local councils. 
(ii)  Temporary land impacts will be compensated for crop losses only.  
(iii)  Permanent  loss  of  residential  or  commercial  land  will  be  compensated  at 
replacement cost based on market rates. DABS will pay transaction costs for titling 
(documentary  stamps,  registration  costs,  etc).  Valuation  will  not  discount  for 
depreciation. 
(iv)  Loss of communal land or property will be compensated with replacement land or 
property in the same village. 
(v)  Buildings or structures losses will be compensated in cash at replacement cost free 
of deductions on account of depreciation and transaction costs. A lump sum shifting 
allowance  based  on  the  current  years  prices  will  be  paid  for  each  affected 
household. 
(vi)  Crop losses will be compensated at market rate for the value of 1 year of production 
plus additional cash assistance at the current year’s prices to purchase seeds and 
restore future crop activities. 
(vii)  Fruit-bearing trees will be compensated at the value of 1 harvest times the number 
of years needed to re-grow a tree at the same productive level of the tree lost. Non-
fruit-bearing trees will be compensated at the cost of reproducing a tree to the 
growth level at which it was cut. Timber trees will be compensated at the commercial 
value of the wood times its volume. No deductions will be applied to the value of the 
wood left to the affected family.  
(viii)  Loss of business will be compensated with a lump sum, one-time allowance for 1 
year income for permanent loss and 6 months income for temporary loss. 
(ix)  Agricultural land tenants, sharecroppers, and workers will be compensated in cash 
equal to 1 full year of income from the lost land. Agricultural workers whose contracts 
will be interrupted will receive an indemnity equivalent to 3 months of income. 
(x)  Loss of community property will be compensated at full replacement value. 
(xi)  Vulnerable households will receive an additional 20% of the total compensation. 
(xii)  If a household’s land is found to be not viable after acquisition, the PMO will help 
affected  persons  prepare  a  deed  of  sale,  which  will  submitted  to  the  district 
government to issue a qabala (title). This will be coordinated by the PMO, and the 
title will be transferred to the project.

Appendix 18  83
11.  Land replacement values will be assessed based on a survey of land sales in project areas 
over the past 3 years and of government rates (if any) as per local revenue papers. If data on land 
market rates are unavailable, affected persons and competent authorities will negotiate land values 
and compensation for other assets. Table A18.2 summarizes these entitlements.

E.  Institutional Arrangements 
12.  The resettlement and rehabilitation program described in this LAR framework involves 
distinct processes, dynamics, and different agencies. DABS as the EA for the planning and 
implementation of the resettlement and rehabilitation program, which also involves the provincial 
and district governments. The PMO, with the support of the management consultant and the 
implementation  consultant,  will  coordinate  all  activities  related  resettlement  planning  and 
implementation. All activities will be coordinated with the relevant local government agencies 
and community in which the projects will be implemented. 
 
1.  Afghanistan Electricity Corporation (DABS) 
13.  Several agencies in Afghanistan are involved in matters related to land administration, 
and land rights. However, they are currently not in a position to fully exercise their mandates 
because of capacity issues and weak institutional structures. To overcome this weakness, 
DABS  has  overall  responsibility  for  the  Investment  Program,  including  preparation, 
implementation, and financing of all LAR tasks and cross-agency coordination. An environment 
and social unit (ESU) will be established within the PMO exclusively for this purpose and will be 
supported by management consultants. The ESU will be responsible internally for monitoring 
LAR plan preparation and implementation (including surveys, asset valuation, and community 
consultation),  LAR-related  cross-agency  and  interdepartmental  coordination,  and  LAR  plan 
approval. Land acquisition will involve the following: 
 
(i)  An ESU will be established in the PMO to handle all LAR. 
(ii)  International and national resettlement specialists will be provided through the 
management consultants. They will assist in LAR planning and implementation, 
internal monitoring and evaluation, and training on impact assessment and ADB 
resettlement policy requirements.

Appendix 18  85
(iii)  Local nongovernment organizations (NGOs) may be engaged to provide on-site 
LAR  plan  preparation  assistance  for  surveys,  information  gathering,  and 
consultations with affected persons. 
(iv)  Implementation consultants for the projects will include one international and one 
national  social  development  and  resettlement  specialist  to  conduct  periodic 
monitoring and evaluation and third-party validation of implementation of project-
specific LAR plan activities, and to liaise with the contractor to ensure smooth 
implementation of related social development and resettlement requirements.  
(v)  As necessary the PMO will coordinate with the Ministry of Agriculture, Irrigation 
and Livestock, Cadastre Survey Department, local governorates, NGOs and the 
community shuras, and locally elected councils. 
 
2.  Other Agencies and Institutions 
14.  ADB will provide clearance for both category ‘A’ and ‘B’ LAR plans.  
 
Table A18.3: Agencies Responsible for Implementation of Resettlement Plan 
No.  Activity  Agency Responsible 
1  Setting up of an ESU in the PMO  DABS 
2  Hiring of resettlement specialist for ESU  PMO 
3  Hiring of implementing NGO  ESU of PMO 
4  Preparing and updating the LAR plan, including verification  ESU of PMO, local government, implementing NGO, 
survey, identification of affected persons, fixing of replacement  and competent authority 
cost, fixing of assistance, and disclosure of LAR plan. 
5  Review and approval of LAR plan  ESU of PMO and ADB 
6  Compensation award and payment of compensation   ESU  of  PMO,  local  administration,  and  competent 
authority  
7  Taking over the possession of acquired land and houses  ESU of PMO and concerned departments 
8  Handing over acquired land to contractors for construction  ESU of PMO 
9  Issuance of NOC   EMA  
10  Restoration of temporarily acquired land to its original state,  Contractors subject to monitoring by implementation 
including restoration of private or common property resources  consultant, EMA, and ESU of PMO 
11  Income restoration activities, particularly for vulnerable groups   Implementing NGO  
11  Internal monitoring  ESU of PMO  
12  External monitoring  EMA 
DABS = Afghanistan Electricity Corporation, EMA = external monitoring agency, ESU = environment and social unit, 
LAR = land acquisition and resettlement, NOC = no-objection certificate, PMO = program management office.  
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
F.  Public Consultation and Documents Disclosure 
15.  All  stakeholders,  including  the  affected  persons  and  local  administration,  provincial, 
district,  and  village  officials,  will  be  informed  and  consulted  about  a  project.  Further,  their 
cooperation will be solicited while conducting the inventory of affected assets and the census of 
affected persons. The affected persons will be consulted and their views on the project layout 
and design, as well as their preferences on compensation and/or other resettlement assistance, 
will  be  recorded  and  given  due  consideration  in  project  planning.  Information  about  the 
entitlement provisions and compensation packages will be shared with the affected persons and 
their comments and suggestions will be incorporated in the LAR plan. LAR plans will detail 
processes and mechanisms to ensure the affected person’s involvement. The plans also will 
include  an  appendix  with  a  list  of  the  consultation  meetings  held  with  date,  number  of 
participants, and minutes of matters discussed.

86   Appendix 18 
16.  The LAR framework in the local language (Dari) will be disclosed to the affected persons 
at the PMO; the same will be done for the LAR plans after the endorsement by EA. The LAR 
framework and LAR plan in English will be posted on ADB’s website after its endorsement by 
the EA. Each LAR plan will be made available in Dari. A LAR information leaflet with LAR 
information,  including  measurement  of  losses,  detailed  asset  valuations,  entitlements  and 
special provisions, grievance procedures, timing of payments and displacement schedule, will 
be made available in Dari and distributed to affected persons. The LAR framework and LAR 
plans disclosure will be a condition to proceed to project appraisal. 
 
G.  Grievance Redress Mechanism 
17.  An adequate grievance redress mechanism for affected persons will be established 
based on a three-stage procedure for redress of grievances and complaints. 
 
18.  The ESU will design a pro forma letter to be used by the affected persons for filing 
complaints. Literate local leaders will be identified for each project to assist the affected persons 
in filling out the form, and to assist them at every stage of the complaints process. Moreover, the 
implementing NGO will help the affected persons in preparing the grievance note and sending it 
to the concerned authority.  
 
H.  Resettlement Budget 
19.  The EA will prepare detailed budgets for each LAR plan. The budget will be included in 
the overall cost estimates for projects. The budget will detail (i) costs for land acquisition, 
houses, crops, relocation, and income restoration; (ii) source of funding; (iii) arrangements for 
approval; (iv) flow of funds; and (v) a 15% contingency. The EA will provide all funds for land 
acquisition. All land acquisition, compensation, relocation, and rehabilitation of income and 
livelihood will be considered an integral component of project costs. The EA will keep advance 
provisional budget in its annual plan for LAR costs. 
I.  Monitoring and Evaluation 
20.  LAR tasks under the Investment Program will be subjected to internal and external 
monitoring. Internal monitoring will be conducted by the ESU of the PMO, assisted by the 
implementation consultant. External monitoring will be assigned to an agency recruited by the 
PMO. ADB will prepare the terms of reference for the external monitoring agency (EMA) before 
LAR plan implementation begins.  
 
1.  Internal Monitoring 
21.  The PMO, through the ESU, will routinely carry out internal monitoring, and the results 
will be communicated to ADB through the quarterly project implementation reports. Indicators 
related to the process, immediate outputs, and results will be used for internal monitoring. This 
information will be collected directly from the field and reported monthly to the PMO to assess 
the  progress  and  results  of  LAR  plan  implementation,  and  to  adjust  the  work  program  if 
necessary. The monthly reports will be consolidated every quarter in the standard supervision 
reports and submitted to ADB. The following will be monitoring benchmarks: (i) information 
campaign and consultation with affected persons, (ii) status of land acquisition and payments on 
land compensation, (iii) compensation for affected structures and other assets, (iv) relocation of 
affected persons, (v) payments for loss of income, (vi) selection and distribution of replacement 
land, and (vii) income-restoration activities.

Appendix 18  87
 
2.  External Monitoring 
22.  External monitoring will be carried out twice a year, and the results will be communicated 
to the PMO and ADB through semiannual reports. The EMA will be recruited annually on an 
intermittent basis up to 1 year after the project works are completed. The EMA will also be 
responsible for (i) issuing a no-objection certification to proceed with work in sections of lots of 
the project where there is no land acquisition; and (ii) for sections or lots where LAR is required, 
completing an audit confirming that all compensation and related resettlement assistance in 
cash or kind has been delivered to the affected households before issuing no-objection to 
proceed.  A  copy  of  the  no-objection  certificate  will  be  submitted  to  the  PMO  (ESU), 
implementation consultant, and ADB simultaneously.  
 
23.  The EMA will also assess the status of vulnerable groups affected by the project, such 
as households headed by women, disabled and/or elderly and poor families. The indicators 
developed  for  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  the  project  will  be  based  on  the  following:  (i) 
socioeconomic conditions of the affected persons after resettlement; (ii) communications and 
reactions from affected persons on, among other things, entitlements, compensation, options, 
alternative developments, and relocation timetables; (iii) changes in housing and income levels; 
(iv)  rehabilitation  of  squatters;  (v)  valuation  of  property;  (vi)  grievance  procedures;  (vii) 
disbursement  of  compensation;  and  (viii)  level  of  satisfaction  of  affected  persons  after 
resettlement. 
 
24.  For each project, the EMA will carry out an evaluation of the LAR plan about 1 year after 
its implementation. The main reason for this study is to find out whether the plan objectives 
were attained. The socioeconomic survey baseline will be used to compare pre- and post-
project conditions. The EMA will recommend supplemental assistance for the affected persons if 
the study shows that the objectives of the LAR plan have not been attained.
